[[Amanda McBroom]]
[[Michele Brourman]] (songs) | cinematography = | editing = [[Ken Solomon]] | studio = [[Universal Animation Studios|Universal Cartoon Studios]] | distributor = [[Universal Pictures Home Entertainment|Universal Studios Home Video]] | released = {{Film date|2004|9|30}} | runtime = 76 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''Balto III: Wings of Change''''' is a 2004 [[direct-to-video]] [[sequel]] to [[Universal Pictures]]'s [[animated films]] [[Balto (film)|Balto]] and [[Balto II: Wolf Quest]]. ==Voice cast== * [[Maurice LaMarche]] as [[Balto]], Moose #1, Moose #2 * [[Sean Astin]] as Kodi * [[Jodi Benson]] as Jenna * [[Charles Fleischer]] as Boris, White Mountain Postmaster * [[Keith Carradine]] as Duke * [[Kevin Schon]] as Muk, Luk, Simpson * [[Jean Smart]] as Stella * [[Bill Fagerbakke]] as Ralph, Mr. Conner * [[Charity James]] as Dusty * [[Kathy Najimy]] as Dipsy * [[David Paymer]] as Mel * [[Carl Weathers]] as Kirby == Music == All of the songs are produced by [[Michele Brourman]] and written by her along with [[Amanda McBroom]]. Original songs performed in the film include: {{Track listing | all_writing = | all_lyrics = | all_music = | extra_column = Performer(s) | title1 = You Don't Have to Be a Hero | extra1 = [[Jodi Benson]] | title2 = Come On Up and Fly | extra2 = Jean Smart (backup vocals by Kimaya Seward and Ken Stacy) | title3 = Everything Flies | extra3 = Kimaya Seward and Ken Stacy }} == References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
Stephen Grover Cleveland (March 18, 1837 – June 24, 1908) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 22nd and 24th president of the United States from 1885 to 1889 and from 1893 to 1897. Cleveland is the only president in American history to serve two nonconsecutive terms in office.[b] He won the popular vote for three presidential elections—in 1884, 1888, and 1892—and was one of two Democrats (followed by Woodrow Wilson in 1912) to be elected president during the era of Republican presidential domination dating from 1861 to 1933.
In 1881, Cleveland was elected mayor of Buffalo and later, governor of New York. He was the leader of the pro-business Bourbon Democrats who opposed high tariffs; Free Silver; inflation; imperialism; and subsidies to business, farmers, or veterans. His crusade for political reform and fiscal conservatism made him an icon for American conservatives of the era.[1] Cleveland won praise for his honesty, self-reliance, integrity, and commitment to the principles of classical liberalism.[2] He fought political corruption, patronage, and bossism. As a reformer, Cleveland had such prestige that the like-minded wing of the Republican Party, called "Mugwumps", largely bolted the GOP presidential ticket and swung to his support in the 1884 election.[3] As his second administration began, disaster hit the nation when the Panic of 1893 produced a severe national depression. It ruined his Democratic Party, opening the way for a Republican landslide in 1894 and for the agrarian and silverite seizure of the Democratic Party in 1896. The result was a political realignment that ended the Third Party System and launched the Fourth Party System and the Progressive Era.[4]
Cleveland was a formidable policymaker, and he also drew corresponding criticism. His intervention in the Pullman Strike of 1894 to keep the railroads moving angered labor unions nationwide in addition to the party in Illinois; his support of the gold standard and opposition to Free Silver alienated the agrarian wing of the Democratic Party.[5] Critics complained that Cleveland had little imagination and seemed overwhelmed by the nation's economic disasters—depressions and strikes—in his second term.[5] Even so, his reputation for probity and good character survived the troubles of his second term. Biographer Allan Nevins wrote, "[I]n Grover Cleveland, the greatness lies in typical rather than unusual qualities. He had no endowments that thousands of men do not have. He possessed honesty, courage, firmness, independence, and common sense. But he possessed them to a degree other men do not."[6] By the end of his second term, public perception showed him to be one of the most unpopular U.S. presidents, and he was by then rejected even by most Democrats.[7] Today, Cleveland is considered by most historians to have been a successful leader, and has been praised for honesty, integrity, adherence to his morals and defying party boundaries, and effective leadership. He is generally ranked among the upper-mid tier of American presidents.
Contents 1 Early life 1.1 Childhood and family history 1.2 Education and moving west 1.3 Early career and the Civil War 2 Political career in New York 2.1 Sheriff of Erie County 2.2 Mayor of Buffalo 2.3 Governor of New York 3 Election of 1884 3.1 Nomination for president 3.2 Campaign against Blaine 4 First presidency (1885–1889) 4.1 Reform 4.2 Vetoes 4.3 Silver 4.4 Tariffs 4.5 Foreign policy, 1885–1889 4.6 Military policy, 1885–1889 4.7 Civil rights and immigration 4.8 Native American policy 4.9 Marriage and children 4.10 Administration and Cabinet 4.11 Judicial appointments 5 Election of 1888 and return to private life (1889–1893) 5.1 Defeated by Harrison 5.2 Private citizen for four years 6 Election of 1892 6.1 Nomination for president 6.2 Campaign against Harrison 7 Second presidency (1893–1897) 7.1 Economic panic and the silver issue 7.2 Tariff reform 7.3 Voting rights 7.4 Labor unrest 7.5 Pullman Strike 7.6 Foreign policy, 1893–1897 7.7 Military policy, 1893–1897 7.8 Cancer 7.9 Administration and cabinet 7.10 Judicial appointments 7.11 States admitted to the Union 8 1896 election and retirement (1897–1908) 9 Illness and death 10 Honors and memorials 11 See also 12 References 12.1 Further reading 13 External links Early life Childhood and family history
Caldwell Presbyterian parsonage, birthplace of Grover Cleveland in Caldwell, New Jersey Stephen Grover Cleveland was born on March 18, 1837, in Caldwell, New Jersey, to Ann (née Neal) and Richard Falley Cleveland.[8] Cleveland's father was a Congregational and Presbyterian minister who was originally from Connecticut.[9] His mother was from Baltimore and was the daughter of a bookseller.[10] On his father's side, Cleveland was descended from English ancestors, the first of the family having emigrated to Massachusetts from Cleveland, England in 1635.[11] His father's maternal grandfather, Richard Falley Jr., fought at the Battle of Bunker Hill, and was the son of an immigrant from Guernsey. On his mother's side, Cleveland was descended from Anglo-Irish Protestants and German Quakers from Philadelphia.[12] Cleveland was distantly related to General Moses Cleaveland, after whom the city of Cleveland, Ohio, was named.[13]
Cleveland, the fifth of nine children, was named Stephen Grover in honor of the first pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Caldwell, where his father was pastor at the time. He became known as Grover in his adult life.[14] In 1841, the Cleveland family moved to Fayetteville, New York, where Grover spent much of his childhood.[15] Neighbors later described him as "full of fun and inclined to play pranks,"[16] and fond of outdoor sports.[17]
In 1850, Cleveland's father Richard moved his family to Clinton, New York, to work as district secretary for the American Home Missionary Society.[18] Despite his father's dedication to his missionary work, his income was insufficient for the large family. Financial conditions forced him to remove Grover from school and place him in a two-year mercantile apprenticeship in Fayetteville. The experience was valuable and brief, and the living conditions quite austere. Grover returned to Clinton and his schooling at the completion of the apprentice contract.[19] In 1853, when missionary work began to take a toll on the health of Cleveland's father, he took an assignment in Holland Patent, New York (near Utica) and moved his family again.[20] Shortly after, he died from a gastric ulcer. The younger Cleveland was said to have learned about his father's death from a boy selling newspapers.[20]
Education and moving west
An early, undated photograph of Grover Cleveland Cleveland received his elementary education at the Fayetteville Academy and the Clinton Liberal Academy.[21] After his father died in 1853, he again left school to help support his family. Later that year, Cleveland's brother William was hired as a teacher at the New York Institute for the Blind in New York City, and William obtained a place for Cleveland as an assistant teacher. Cleveland returned home to Holland Patent at the end of 1854, where an elder in his church offered to pay for his college education if he would promise to become a minister. Cleveland declined, and in 1855 he decided to move west.[22]
He stopped first in Buffalo, New York, where his uncle, Lewis F. Allen, gave him a clerical job.[23] Allen was an important man in Buffalo, and he introduced his nephew to influential men there, including the partners in the law firm of Rogers, Bowen, and Rogers.[24] Millard Fillmore, the 13th president of the United States, had previously worked for the partnership.[25] Cleveland later took a clerkship with the firm, began to read the law with them, and was admitted to the New York bar in 1859.[26]
Early career and the Civil War Cleveland worked for the Rogers firm for three years before leaving in 1862 to start his own practice.[27] In January 1863, he was appointed assistant district attorney of Erie County.[28] With the American Civil War raging, Congress passed the Conscription Act of 1863, requiring able-bodied men to serve in the army if called upon, or else to hire a substitute.[26] Cleveland chose the latter course, paying $150 (equivalent to $3,153 in 2020) to George Benninsky, a thirty-two-year-old Polish immigrant, to serve in his place.[29] Benninsky survived the war.[26]
As a lawyer, Cleveland became known for his single-minded concentration and dedication to hard work.[30] In 1866, he successfully defended some participants in the Fenian raid, working on a pro bono basis (free of charge).[31] In 1868, Cleveland attracted professional attention for his winning defense of a libel suit against the editor of Buffalo's Commercial Advertiser.[32] During this time, Cleveland assumed a lifestyle of simplicity, taking residence in a plain boarding house. He devoted his growing income instead to the support of his mother and younger sisters.[33] While his personal quarters were austere, Cleveland enjoyed an active social life and "the easy-going sociability of hotel-lobbies and saloons."[34] He shunned the circles of higher society of Buffalo in which his uncle's family traveled.[35]
Political career in New York Sheriff of Erie County
Statue of Grover Cleveland outside City Hall in Buffalo, New York From his earliest involvement in politics, Cleveland aligned with the Democratic Party.[36] He had a decided aversion to Republicans John Fremont and Abraham Lincoln, and the heads of the Rogers law firm were solid Democrats.[37] In 1865, he ran for District Attorney, losing narrowly to his friend and roommate, Lyman K. Bass, the Republican nominee.[30]
In 1870, with the help of friend Oscar Folsom, Cleveland secured the Democratic nomination for Sheriff of Erie County, New York.[38] He won the election by a 303-vote margin and took office on January 1, 1871, at age 33.[39][40] While this new career took him away from the practice of law, it was rewarding in other ways: the fees were said to yield up to $40,000 (equivalent to $864,111 in 2020) over the two-year term.[38]
Cleveland's service as sheriff was unremarkable; biographer Rexford Tugwell described the time in office as a waste for Cleveland politically. Cleveland was aware of graft in the sheriff's office during his tenure and chose not to confront it.[41] A notable incident of his term took place on September 6, 1872, when Patrick Morrissey was executed. He had been convicted of murdering his mother.[42] As sheriff, Cleveland was responsible for either personally carrying out the execution or paying a deputy $10 to perform the task.[42] In spite of reservations about the hanging, Cleveland executed Morrissey himself.[42] He hanged another murderer, John Gaffney, on February 14, 1873.[43]
After his term as sheriff ended, Cleveland returned to his law practice, opening a firm with his friends Lyman K. Bass and Wilson S. Bissell.[44] Elected to Congress in 1872, Bass did not spend much time at the firm, but Cleveland and Bissell soon rose to the top of Buffalo's legal community.[45] Up to that point, Cleveland's political career had been honorable and unexceptional. As biographer Allan Nevins wrote, "Probably no man in the country, on March 4, 1881, had less thought than this limited, simple, sturdy attorney of Buffalo that four years later he would be standing in Washington and taking the oath as President of the United States."[46]
It was during this period that Cleveland began courting a widow, Maria Halpin. She later accused him of raping her.[47][48] He accused her of being an alcoholic and consorting with men. In an attempt to discredit her, he had her institutionalized and had their child taken away and raised by his friends. The institution quickly realized that she did not belong there and released her.[49] The illegitimate child became a campaign issue for the GOP in Cleveland's first presidential campaign.[50]
Mayor of Buffalo In the 1870s, the municipal government in Buffalo had grown increasingly corrupt, with Democratic and Republican political machines cooperating to share the spoils of political office.[51] In 1881 the Republicans nominated a slate of particularly disreputable machine politicians; the Democrats saw the opportunity to gain the votes of disaffected Republicans by nominating a more honest candidate.[52] The party leaders approached Cleveland, and he agreed to run for Mayor of Buffalo, provided that the rest of the ticket was to his liking.[53] When the more notorious politicians were left off the Democratic ticket, Cleveland accepted the nomination.[53] Cleveland was elected mayor with 15,120 votes, as against 11,528 for Milton C. Beebe, his opponent.[54] He took office January 2, 1882.
Cleveland's term as mayor was spent fighting the entrenched interests of the party machines.[55] Among the acts that established his reputation was a veto of the street-cleaning bill passed by the Common Council.[56] The street-cleaning contract had been competed for bidding, and the Council selected the highest bidder at $422,000, rather than the lowest of $100,000 less, because of the political connections of the bidder.[56] While this sort of bipartisan graft had previously been tolerated in Buffalo, Mayor Cleveland would have none of it. His veto message said, "I regard it as the culmination of a most bare-faced, impudent, and shameless scheme to betray the interests of the people, and to worse than squander the public money."[57] The Council reversed itself and awarded the contract to the lowest bidder.[58] Cleveland also asked the state legislature to form a Commission to develop a plan to improve the sewer system in Buffalo at a much lower cost than previously proposed locally; this plan was successfully adopted.[59] For this, and other actions safeguarding public funds, Cleveland began to gain a reputation beyond Erie County as a leader willing to purge government corruption.[60]
Governor of New York
Gubernatorial portrait of Grover Cleveland New York Democratic party officials began to consider Cleveland a possible nominee for governor.[61] Daniel Manning, a party insider who admired Cleveland's record, was instrumental in his candidacy.[62] With a split in the state Republican party in 1882, the Democratic party was considered to be at an advantage; several men contended for that party's nomination.[61] The two leading Democratic candidates were Roswell P. Flower and Henry W. Slocum. Their factions deadlocked, and the convention could not agree on a nominee.[63] Cleveland, in third place on the first ballot, picked up support in subsequent votes and emerged as the compromise choice.[64] The Republican party remained divided, and in the general election Cleveland emerged the victor, with 535,318 votes to Republican nominee Charles J. Folger's 342,464.[65] Cleveland's margin of victory was, at the time, the largest in a contested New York election; the Democrats also picked up seats in both houses of the New York State Legislature.[66]
Cleveland brought his opposition to needless spending to the governor's office; he promptly sent the legislature eight vetoes in his first two months in office.[67] The first to attract attention was his veto of a bill to reduce the fares on New York City elevated trains to five cents.[68] The bill had broad support because the trains' owner, Jay Gould, was unpopular, and his fare increases were widely denounced.[69] Cleveland, however, saw the bill as unjust—Gould had taken over the railroads when they were failing and had made the system solvent again.[70] Moreover, Cleveland believed that altering Gould's franchise would violate the Contract Clause of the federal Constitution.[70] Despite the initial popularity of the fare-reduction bill, the newspapers praised Cleveland's veto.[70] Theodore Roosevelt, then a member of the Assembly, had reluctantly voted for the bill to which Cleveland objected, in a desire to punish the unscrupulous railroad barons.[71] After the veto, Roosevelt reversed himself, as did many legislators, and the veto was sustained.[71]
Cleveland's defiance of political corruption won him popular acclaim, and the enmity of the influential Tammany Hall organization in New York City.[72] Tammany, under its boss, John Kelly, had disapproved of Cleveland's nomination as governor, and their resistance intensified after Cleveland openly opposed and prevented the re-election of Thomas F. Grady, their point man in the State Senate.[73] Cleveland also steadfastly opposed nominees of the Tammanyites, as well as bills passed as a result of their deal-making.[74] The loss of Tammany's support was offset by the support of Theodore Roosevelt and other reform-minded Republicans who helped Cleveland to pass several laws reforming municipal governments.[75]
Election of 1884 Main articles: 1884 United States presidential election and Grover Cleveland 1884 presidential campaign Nomination for president Main article: 1884 Democratic National Convention
An anti-Blaine cartoon presents him as the "tattooed man", with many indelible scandals.
An anti-Cleveland cartoon highlights the Halpin scandal. The Republicans convened in Chicago and nominated former Speaker of the House James G. Blaine of Maine for president on the fourth ballot. Blaine's nomination alienated many Republicans who viewed Blaine as ambitious and immoral.[76] The GOP standard-bearer was weakened by alienating the Mugwumps, and the Conkling faction, recently disenfranchised by President Chester Arthur.[77] Democratic party leaders believed the Republicans' choice gave them an opportunity to win the White House for the first time since 1856 if the right candidate could be found.[76]
Among the Democrats, Samuel J. Tilden was the initial front-runner, having been the party's nominee in the contested election of 1876.[78] After Tilden declined a nomination due to his poor health, his supporters shifted to several other contenders.[78] Cleveland was among the leaders in early support, and Thomas F. Bayard of Delaware, Allen G. Thurman of Ohio, Samuel Freeman Miller of Iowa, and Benjamin Butler of Massachusetts also had considerable followings, along with various favorite sons.[78] Each of the other candidates had hindrances to his nomination: Bayard had spoken in favor of secession in 1861, making him unacceptable to Northerners; Butler, conversely, was reviled throughout the South for his actions during the Civil War; Thurman was generally well-liked, but was growing old and infirm, and his views on the silver question were uncertain.[79]
Cleveland, too, had detractors—Tammany remained opposed to him—but the nature of his enemies made him still more friends.[80] Cleveland led on the first ballot, with 392 votes out of 820.[81] On the second ballot, Tammany threw its support behind Butler, but the rest of the delegates shifted to Cleveland, who won.[82] Thomas A. Hendricks of Indiana was selected as his running mate.[82]
Campaign against Blaine Corruption in politics was the central issue in 1884; Blaine had over the span of his career been involved in several questionable deals.[83] Cleveland's reputation as an opponent of corruption proved the Democrats' strongest asset.[84] William C. Hudson created Cleveland's contextual campaign slogan "A public office is a public trust."[85] Reform-minded Republicans called "Mugwumps" denounced Blaine as corrupt and flocked to Cleveland.[86] The Mugwumps, including such men as Carl Schurz and Henry Ward Beecher, were more concerned with morality than with party, and felt Cleveland was a kindred soul who would promote civil service reform and fight for efficiency in government.[86] At the same time that the Democrats gained support from the Mugwumps, they lost some blue-collar workers to the Greenback-Labor party, led by ex-Democrat Benjamin Butler.[87] In general, Cleveland abided by the precedent of minimizing presidential campaign travel and speechmaking; Blaine became one of the first to break with that tradition.[88]
The campaign focused on the candidates' moral standards, as each side cast aspersions on their opponents. Cleveland's supporters rehashed the old allegations that Blaine had corruptly influenced legislation in favor of the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad and the Union Pacific Railway, later profiting on the sale of bonds he owned in both companies.[89] Although the stories of Blaine's favors to the railroads had made the rounds eight years earlier, this time Blaine's correspondence was discovered, making his earlier denials less plausible.[89] On some of the most damaging correspondence, Blaine had written "Burn this letter", giving Democrats the last line to their rallying cry: "Blaine, Blaine, James G. Blaine, the continental liar from the state of Maine, 'Burn this letter!'"[90]
Regarding Cleveland, commentator Jeff Jacoby notes that, "Not since George Washington had a candidate for President been so renowned for his rectitude."[91] But the Republicans found a refutation buried in Cleveland's past. Aided by the sermons of Reverend George H. Ball, a minister from Buffalo, they made public the allegation that Cleveland had fathered an illegitimate child while he was a lawyer there,[92] and their rallies soon included the chant "Ma, Ma, where's my Pa?".[93] When confronted with the scandal, Cleveland immediately instructed his supporters to "Above all, tell the truth."[50] Cleveland admitted to paying child support in 1874 to Maria Crofts Halpin, the woman who asserted he had fathered her son Oscar Folsom Cleveland and he assumed responsibility.[50] Shortly before the 1884 election, the Republican media published an affidavit from Halpin in which she stated that until she met Cleveland, her "life was pure and spotless", and "there is not, and never was, a doubt as to the paternity of our child, and the attempt of Grover Cleveland, or his friends, to couple the name of Oscar Folsom, or any one else, with that boy, for that purpose is simply infamous and false."[94]
Results of the 1884 election The electoral votes of closely contested New York, New Jersey, Indiana, and Connecticut would determine the election.[95] In New York, the Tammany Democrats decided that they would gain more from supporting a Democrat they disliked than a Republican who would do nothing for them.[96] Blaine hoped that he would have more support from Irish Americans than Republicans typically did; while the Irish were mainly a Democratic constituency in the 19th century, Blaine's mother was Irish Catholic, and he had been supportive of the Irish National Land League while he was Secretary of State.[97] The Irish, a significant group in three of the swing states, did appear inclined to support Blaine until a Republican, Samuel D. Burchard, gave a speech pivotal for the Democrats, denouncing them as the party of "Rum, Romanism, and Rebellion".[98] The Democrats spread the word of this implied Catholic insult on the eve of the election. They also blistered Blaine for attending a banquet with some of New York City's wealthiest men.[99]
After the votes were counted, Cleveland narrowly won all four of the swing states, including New York by 1200 votes.[100] While the popular vote total was close, with Cleveland winning by just one-quarter of a percent, the electoral votes gave Cleveland a majority of 219–182.[100] Following the electoral victory, the "Ma, Ma ..." attack phrase gained a classic riposte: "Gone to the White House. Ha! Ha! Ha!"[101]
First presidency (1885–1889) Main article: Presidencies of Grover Cleveland § First presidency (1885–1889) Reform
Cleveland portrayed as a tariff reformer Soon after taking office, Cleveland was faced with the task of filling all the government jobs for which the president had the power of appointment. These jobs were typically filled under the spoils system, but Cleveland announced that he would not fire any Republican who was doing his job well, and would not appoint anyone solely on the basis of party service.[102] He also used his appointment powers to reduce the number of federal employees, as many departments had become bloated with political time-servers.[103] Later in his term, as his fellow Democrats chafed at being excluded from the spoils, Cleveland began to replace more of the partisan Republican officeholders with Democrats;[104] this was especially the case with policymaking positions.[105] While some of his decisions were influenced by party concerns, more of Cleveland's appointments were decided by merit alone than was the case in his predecessors' administrations.[106]
Cleveland also reformed other parts of the government. In 1887, he signed an act creating the Interstate Commerce Commission.[107] He and Secretary of the Navy William C. Whitney undertook to modernize the navy and canceled construction contracts that had resulted in inferior ships.[108] Cleveland angered railroad investors by ordering an investigation of western lands they held by government grant.[109] Secretary of the Interior Lucius Q. C. Lamar charged that the rights of way for this land must be returned to the public because the railroads failed to extend their lines according to agreements.[109] The lands were forfeited, resulting in the return of approximately 81,000,000 acres (330,000 km2).[109]
Cleveland was the first Democratic president subject to the Tenure of Office Act which originated in 1867; the act purported to require the Senate to approve the dismissal of any presidential appointee who was originally subject to its advice and consent. Cleveland objected to the act in principle and his steadfast refusal to abide by it prompted its fall into disfavor and led to its ultimate repeal in 1887.[110]
Vetoes

revision.text:
{{Infobox person/Wikidata|qid=Q108892256|fetchwikidata=ALL|dateformat=mdy}}
'''Jean Ross Howard Phelan''' is the founder of the [[Whirly-Girls|Whirly Girls]] and the 13th woman in the world to earn her helicopter accreditation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Patricia|date=2004-02-05|title=Jean Ross Howard Phelan Dies at 87|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/2004/02/05/jean-ross-howard-phelan-dies-at-87/eb82f759-349a-4af6-8391-05c95ef26617/|access-date=2021-11-01|issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Slideshow {{!}} NASM.1995.0062_ref517|url=https://edan.si.edu/slideshow/viewer/?eadrefid=NASM.1995.0062_ref517|access-date=2021-11-01|website=edan.si.edu}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title=Jean Ross Howard {{!}} Women in Aviation International|url=https://www.wai.org/pioneers/1995/jean-ross-howard|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.wai.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=CONTENTdm|url=https://twudigital.contentdm.oclc.org/digital/collection/p16283coll1|access-date=2021-11-01|website=twudigital.contentdm.oclc.org}}</ref>
== Personal life == She was born on September 5, 1916 as Jean Ross Howard.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title=Texas Archival Resources Online|url=https://txarchives.org/twu/finding_aids/00008.xml|access-date=2021-11-01|website=txarchives.org}}</ref> Her grandfather was John W. Ross, .
== Education == Phelan attended [[Sidwell Friends School]] and Western High School.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> She went to [[Connecticut College]] and then transferred to [[George Washington University]], where she received a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[history]] in 1939.<ref name=":0" /> In 1955, she earned a [[master's degree]] in history from [[American University]] with her thesis on "Selected Economic Problems in the Operation of Common Carrier Helicopters."<ref name=":2" />
== Career == Phelan worked briefly at [[Eastern Air Lines|Eastern Airlines]] as a reservations clerk.<ref name=":0" /> Phelan, after being inspired by [[Jacqueline Cochran|Jackie Cochran]], signed up but did not complete the Women's Airforce Service Pilots training.<ref name=":0" /> She did earn her pilot's license in 1941.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title=Historical Members - Texas Woman's University|url=https://twu.edu/library/womans-collection/collections/women-in-aviation/whirly-girls-international/history/historical-members/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=twu.edu}}</ref> Phelan was asked to stay by Cochran to help run the [[Women Airforce Service Pilots]] school.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title=Mss 825.1.7|url=https://twudigital.contentdm.oclc.org/digital/collection/p16283coll1/id/6/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=twudigital.contentdm.oclc.org|language=en}}</ref> After a year, she joined the [[Civil Air Patrol]], worked for the Red Cross, and then joined the [[Aircraft Industries Association]] as an administrative aide in the helicopter division.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
In 1954, after convincing her supervisor to allow her to train at the Bell Helicopter School in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Forth Worth, Texas]] and 18 days of training, Jean became the eight American woman and 13th woman worldwide to earn her helicopter accreditation.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
In 1955, she founded the Whirly-Girls International with the goal of building a community of support for women helicopter pilots.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
She retired as director of helicopter activities in 1986.<ref name=":2" />
== Awards and Recognition == Phelan was also the first woman chair of the [[American Helicopter Society]]'s Annual Forum, hosting forums in 1958 and 1959.<ref name=":2" /> For her contributions to the Washington, D.C. aviation community, Jean was presented with the Washington Air Derby Association Trophy in 1963.<ref name=":2" /> From 1966 to 1968, she was elected president of the American Women's News Club.<ref name=":2" /> In 1969, she was awarded the Lady Drummond Hay Trophy, granted by the Women's International Association of Aeronautics.<ref name=":2" />
Phelan was inducted into the Women in Aviation International's Hall of Fame in 1995.<ref name=":1" />
In 2003, Phelan was named as one of the "100 Women Who Made A Difference" by [[Women in Aviation International|Women in Aviation]].<ref name=":2" />
== Death == Phelan died at the age of 87 on January 29, 2004 at [[George Washington University]] Medical Center.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== Resources ==
{{Empty section|date=November 2021}}

{{AFC submission|d|bio|u=Jrryjude|ns=118|decliner=Theroadislong|declinets=20211101200407|ts=20211101200053}} <!-- Do not remove this line! -->
{{AFC comment|1=please read [[WP:REFB]] for help with correctly formatting sources and note that blogs are not usually considered reliable. [[User:Theroadislong|Theroadislong]] ([[User talk:Theroadislong|talk]]) 20:04, 1 November 2021 (UTC)}}
----
'''William W. Stow''' (1824-1895) was the speaker of the California House - 1855, anti-Semitic, California Gubernatorial candidate of the Nativist Know Nothing Party, powerful attorney representing Collis P. Huntington and the Southern Pacific Railroad, and Commissioner of Parks in San Francisco. Stow Lake, in the Golden Gate Park, is named in his honor.
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}} *[https://mountainviewpeople.blogspot.com/2009/07/william-stow-1824-1895-attorney.html] *[https://www.jweekly.com/2019/12/06/this-s-f-lake-is-named-after-californias-most-anti-semitic-politician-one-man-is-trying-to-change-that/]

Declining submission: corp - Submission is about a company or organization not yet shown to meet notability guidelines ([[WP:AFCH|AFCH]] 0.9.1)
revision.text:
{{AFC submission|d|corp|u=2A02:A210:2204:7080:122:D86E:CFA:29A9|ns=118|decliner=Nomadicghumakkad|declinets=20211101203632|ts=20211101200810}} <!-- Do not remove this line! -->
Deliverect is a Ghent-based startup founded by Zhong Xu, Jan Hollez, Jelte Vrijhoef, and Jerome Laredo in September 2018. Deliverect provides restaurants, dark kitchens and FMCG companies with an integrated solution to streamline and easily manage orders from online and third-party sources.
History
The inspiration for the company dates back to a time when Zhong Xu’s father, who was an Asian transplant to Belgium, had built a point of sale(PoS) system that he sold to the Chinese restaurants, hoping that his son would take over that business. Zhong saw that the problem was bigger than just the range of businesses his father was targeting. That first led Zhong and Jan to found POSiOS in 2011, the first iPad-based point of sale solution in Europe. 4 years later it was acquired by Lightspeed.<ref>{{Cite web|title=POSIOS - Crunchbase Company Profile & Funding|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/posios|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Crunchbase|language=en}}</ref>
In 2018, Deliverect was founded with a solution which integrates multiple hospitality systems such as online ordering, in-house dining, inventory management and more into a single SaaS platform that manages all of these different channels in one place.
Overview
Deliverect has processed more than 70 million orders. The platform eliminates the need to monitor multiple devices and manually re-enter orders into their existing system reducing both restaurant staff workload and number of errors.
The features are augmented by multi-sourced data to help the restaurants in making business decisions to help improve order accuracy and save time and labor, with the goal of increasing revenue.
Awards and Accolades
In 2018, Deliverect won innovation awards at Belgium’s Horeca Expo.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Deliverect, the ‘Adyen of food delivery services’ raises €3M of fresh funding and wants to transform the restaurant industry {{!}} Silicon Canals|url=https://siliconcanals.com/news/startups/deliverect-the-adyen-of-food-delivery-services-raises-e3m-of-fresh-funding-and-wants-to-transform-the-restaurant-industry/|access-date=2021-11-01|language=en-US}}</ref> Later in 2019, they won Dutch hospitality fair Horecava awards. Both prizes were given to Deliverect’s solution for addressing a critical problem in the hospitality industry raised due to the rapid growth of the online delivery market. The same year they also received the Tech Product of the Year Award.
Partnerships and Integrations
Deliverect integrates online orders from different food delivery channels, such as Uber Eats, Doordash, Zomato and more. It also works with many cloud kitchens and restaurant chains supporting over 10,000 establishments, in over 30 markets around the world, including brands such as Pret a Manger, Taco Bell, TimeOut Markets, Taqueria, Le Pain Quotidien and Dishoom.
Funding
In 2019, Deliverect received Series A funding of €3M led by Newion and Smartfin.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Deliverect raises €3m in funding for smart POS technology|url=https://www.verdictfoodservice.com/news/deliverect-funding/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.verdictfoodservice.com|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In 2020, Deliverect received Series B funding of €16.3M led by OMERS Ventures.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Cherubini2020-04-29T08:00:00+01:00|first=Elena|title=Belgian food tech startup Deliverect raises €16.3m to expand internationally|url=https://www.thegrocer.co.uk/fundraising/belgian-food-tech-startup-deliverect-raises-163m-to-expand-internationally/604391.article|access-date=2021-11-01|website=The Grocer|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=12 Benelux startups with the fastest-growing teams {{!}} Sifted|url=https://sifted.eu/articles/12-benelux-startups-with-the-fastest-growing-teams/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=sifted.eu}}</ref>
In 2021, Deliverect received Series C funding of $65M led by DST Global Partners, Redpoint ventures.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Deliverect gobbles up $65M for a platform that streamlines online and offline food orders|url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2021/04/20/deliverect-gobbles-up-65m-for-a-platform-that-streamlines-online-and-offline-food-orders/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=TechCrunch|language=en-US}}</ref>
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{In use|section}} {{Dispute|date=September 2021}} {{Unreliable sources|date=November 2021}} {{Expand Persian|date=November 2021}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2021}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Reza Tajbakhsh | birth_name = Mohammadreza Tajbakhsh | origin = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = Reza Tajbakhsh.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|11|18|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], Iran | module = {{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | genre = {{flat list| * [[Iranian pop music|Persian pop]] * [[jazz fusion]] }} | instruments = {{flat list| * piano * keyboards * bass }} | occupation = {{flat list| * [[pianist]] * [[composer]] * [[arranger]] * [[music producer]] * [[bandleader]] }} | years_active = 1990–present | label ={{flat list| * Avaye Barbod * Zang Records }} | associated_acts = [[Zarbofoot|Zarb O Foot]] | website = [https://www.rezatajbakhsh.com/ Official website] }} }} '''Reza Tajbakhsh''' ({{lang-fa|رضا تاجبخش}}; born November 18, 1981) is an Iranian [[musician]], [[pianist]], [[composer]], [[producer]] and [[Bandleader]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش|url=https://www.mehrnews.com/tag/%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7+%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4|access-date=2021-10-22|website=خبرگزاری مهر {{!}} اخبار ایران و جهان {{!}} Mehr News Agency|language=fa}}</ref><ref>https://www.tasnimnews.com/fa/news/1394/12/24/1027789</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=فر|first=ایمان انصاری|date=2020-10-02|title=رضا تاجبخش ، اخبار موسیقی ،اخبار موسیقی ایران ، واوموزیک،vavmusic|url=http://vavmusic.com/wYMoI|access-date=2021-10-22|website=واو موزیک - دانلود آهنگ جدید ایرانی|language=Persian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=جدیدترین خبرهای «رضا تاجبخش» - خبربان|url=https://khabarban.com/w/%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4|access-date=2021-10-22|website=khabarban.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش: کرونا لطف بزرگی به صنعت موسیقی ما کرد|url=http://www.honaronline.ir/بخش-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C-5/153460-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%DA%A9%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7-%D9%84%D8%B7%D9%81-%D8%A8%D8%B2%D8%B1%DA%AF%DB%8C-%D8%A8%D9%87-%D8%B5%D9%86%D8%B9%D8%AA-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C-%D9%85%D8%A7-%DA%A9%D8%B1%D8%AF|access-date=2021-10-22|website=خبرگزاری هنر ایران|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Bellefeuille|first=Jean|date=2019-11-20|title=Reza Tajbakhsh|url=https://kurzweil.com/2019/11/20/reza_tajbakhsh/|access-date=2021-10-22|website=KURZWEIL It's the Sound®|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Biography == Reza Tajbakhsh was born 18 November 1981 in Tehran, iran.<ref>{{Cite web|title=بیوگرافی رضا تاجبخش آهنگساز و نوازنده پیانو ایرانی|url=https://www.beytoote.com/art/artist/biography-pianist2-rezatajbakhsh.html|access-date=2021-10-22|website=www.beytoote.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش Archives|url=https://www.musicepars.com/tag/رضا-تاجبخش/|access-date=2021-10-22|website=سايت خبری تحليلی موسيقی پارس :: اخبار موسيقی :: گزارش کنسرت|language=fa-IR}}</ref>He started his musical appearance as a pianist in 1990. Later in the early 2000 he entered the Music industry officially.<ref>{{Cite web|last=https://plus.google.com/113403756129291503583|date=2017-06-19|title=Iranian Young Musician to Release First Album|url=https://financialtribune.com/articles/art-and-culture/66772/iranian-young-musician-to-release-first-album|access-date=2021-10-22|website=Financial Tribune|language=En}}</ref> Since 2000 he has led several bands for the most eminent Iranian pop singers such as Hamid Hami, Hamid Khandan, Mani Rahnama, Nima Masiha, [[Babak Jahanbakhsh]], [[Sirvan Khosravi]] and [[Amir Tajik]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=آخرین اخبار رضا تاجبخش|url=https://navatv.com/tag/%d8%b1%d8%b6%d8%a7-%d8%aa%d8%a7%d8%ac%d8%a8%d8%ae%d8%b4|access-date=2021-10-22|website=رسانه نوا|language=fa-IR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش با شش خواننده «عاشقانه‌های پاپ» را برگزار می‌کند|url=https://www.ilna.news/بخش-%D9%81%D8%B1%D9%87%D9%86%DA%AF-%D9%87%D9%86%D8%B1-6/614896-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%B4%D8%B4-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%87-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%B1%DA%AF%D8%B2%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%85%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%AF|access-date=2021-10-22|website=خبرگزاری ایلنا|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=اجرای ۶ خواننده پاپ در یک کنسرت/ حضور نوازندگان ارکستر سمفونیک در یک کنسرت پاپ {{!}} خبرگزاری فارس|url=https://www.farsnews.ir/news/13970225000579/%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%B1%D8%A7%DB%8C-%DB%B6-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%87-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%DB%8C%DA%A9-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%AA-%D8%AD%D8%B6%D9%88%D8%B1-%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%A7%D8%B1%DA%A9%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D8%B3%D9%85%D9%81%D9%88%D9%86%DB%8C%DA%A9-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%DB%8C%DA%A9|access-date=2021-10-22|website=www.farsnews.ir}}</ref><ref>[https://www.borna.news/%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B1-64/136669-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B1%D9%81%DB%8C-%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%81%DB%8C%DA%A9-%D8%A7%D8%B4%DA%A9%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AE%D8%B7%DB%8C%D8%A8%DB%8C رضا تاجبخش در خبرگزاری برنا]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش از کویر خواند + جزئیات|url=https://www.rokna.net/بخش-%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%B3%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%B1%DB%8C%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D9%87%D8%A7-6/573211-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%D8%A7%D8%B2-%DA%A9%D9%88%DB%8C%D8%B1-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%B2%D8%A6%DB%8C%D8%A7%D8%AA|access-date=2021-10-23|website=رکنا|language=fa}}</ref>
== Career == {{BLP sources section|date=November 2017}} His main musical focus is on the style of Latin Jazz which is obviously audible in his performances with his band "E-Jazz" , as he performed several concerts in this genre. As the leader of a Jazz Trio named “E-Jazz”, he performed a number of successful concerts in the great Vahdat Hall in his hometown Tehran-Iran.<ref>https://www.tasnimnews.com/fa/news/1399/01/19/2238542</ref> His repertoire contains both Standard Jazz and some of his own compositions as well. <ref>{{Cite web|title=کنسرت روزبه بمانی با تقدیر از سینماگران و اجرای یک قطعه جدید|url=https://www.mojnews.com/بخش-%D9%81%D8%B1%D9%87%D9%86%DA%AF%DB%8C-6/292839-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%AA-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B2%D8%A8%D9%87-%D8%A8%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%86%D9%85%D8%A7%DA%AF%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%B1%D8%A7%DB%8C-%DB%8C%DA%A9-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B9%D9%87-%D8%AC%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%AF|access-date=2021-10-22|website=خبرگزاری موج|language=fa}}</ref><ref>https://www.yjc.news/fa/news/6880550</ref><ref>https://aftabnews.ir/fa/news/524234</ref>
Reza’s performances are famous in the creative combination of communication and instructive ways he brings to the audience.<ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش|url=https://www.musicema.com/Reza-Tajbakhsh|access-date=2021-10-22|website=Musicema.com|language=fa}}</ref> As a part of his 2 hour concerts he usually plays a riff to the crowd and ask them to sing/hum it, then he manipulates that riff by adding other creative elements right on the fly.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-04-15|title=کنسرت «عاشقانه‌های پاپ» در تهران {{!}} آوای فردا|url=https://avayefarda.com/28518/|access-date=2021-10-22|website=آوای فردا {{!}} رسانه خبری تحلیلی موسیقی ایران|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=هنوز راه زیادی در پیش دارم|url=https://khabarfarsi.com/u/8883331|access-date=2021-10-22|website=KhabarFarsi.com|language=fa}}</ref><ref>https://www.hamshahrionline.ir/news/302899</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=نشست ترانه – آواز با حضور امیرعباس گلاب و رضا تاجبخش برگزار می شود|url=https://khabarfarsi.com/u/53551282|access-date=2021-10-23|website=KhabarFarsi.com|language=fa}}</ref>
=== Tehran Symphony Orchestra === Appeared as guest artist in [[Tehran Symphony Orchestra|Tehran Symphonic Orchestra]] performances.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-04-16|title=رضا تاجبخش: کنسرت عاشقانه های پاپ با خوانندگی سوپراستارهای موسیقی و همراهی ارکستر سمفونیک برگزار می شود|url=https://tribunehonar.com/?p=21870|access-date=2021-10-22|website=تریبون هنر|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Group|first=Arya|title=خبرگزاری آریا - اين مهم‌ترين کنسرت پاپ بعد از انقلاب است|url=https://www.aryanews.com/News/120180429175234091/اين-مهم‌ترين-کنسرت-پاپ-بعد-از-انقلاب-است|access-date=2021-10-22|website=www.aryanews.com|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2011-03-05|title=آلبوم موسيقي پاپ «ترديد» منتشر شد|url=https://www.isna.ir/news/8912-09334/آلبوم-موسيقي-پاپ-ترديد-منتشر-شد|access-date=2021-10-22|website=ایسنا|language=fa}}</ref>In 2015, he released a piece [[:fa:بر_فراز_آسمان‌ها|Above the Skies]], which was released with the voice of [[Ebi]] in the final version of the film Above the Skies, performed by Nima Masiha, composed by Shahrdad Rouhani and arranged by him.<ref>{{Cite web|title=یکی از قطعات «شهرداد روحانی» توسط «رضا تاجبخش» تنظیم و با صدای «نیما مسیحا» اجرا شد|url=https://www.musicema.com/node/233840|access-date=2021-10-26|website=Musicema.com|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=YJC|first=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران {{!}} آخرین اخبار ایران و جهان {{!}}|date=۱۳۹۴/۰۳/۲۴ - ۱۰:۰۰|title=«بر فراز آسمان‌ها» با صدای نیما مسیحا به شهرداد روحانی تقدیم می‌شود|url=http://www.yjc.news/fa/news/5231049|access-date=2021-10-26|website=fa|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2014-08-12|title=لاچینی و «گفتگو با خدا در ساعت 11:11»|url=https://www.isna.ir/news/93052110466/لاچینی-و-گفتگو-با-خدا-در-ساعت-11-11|access-date=2021-10-28|website=ایسنا|language=fa}}</ref>
=== Zarbofoot === While he is working on his own album at the moment, He is also busy performing as a member of the first Iranian Electro Jazz Lounge band called” [[Zarbofoot|Zarb O Foot]]”,<ref>{{Cite web|title=The band – ZARBOFOOT|url=https://zarbofoot.com/index.php/the-band/|access-date=2021-10-23|language=en-GB}}</ref> which had their first successful performance in the Niavaran Cultural Center Last November.<ref>{{Cite web|last=اسلامی|first=وزارت فرهنگ و ارشاد|title=خاطره انگیز ترین ترانه های پاپ و کلاسیک|url=https://fniavaran.ir/fa/news/175995/%d8%ae%d8%a7%d8%b7%d8%b1%d9%87-%d8%a7%d9%86%da%af%db%8c%d8%b2-%d8%aa%d8%b1%db%8c%d9%86-%d8%aa%d8%b1%d8%a7%d9%86%d9%87-%d9%87%d8%a7%db%8c-%d9%be%d8%a7%d9%be-%d9%88-%da%a9%d9%84%d8%a7%d8%b3%db%8c%da%a9|access-date=2021-10-22|website=وزارت فرهنگ و ارشاد اسلامی|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=روزنامه خراسان|url=http://www.khorasannews.com/|access-date=2021-10-22|website=www.khorasannews.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش|url=https://etemadonline.com/topics/95297/%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7%20%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4|access-date=2021-10-22|website=اعتمادآنلاین|language=fa}}</ref>
=== Fajr Music Festival === Reza Tajbakhsh was present at the closing ceremony of the [[Fajr International Music Festival|33rd Fajr International Music Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=پرونده جشنواره ۳۳ بسته شد/ تقدیم جایزه ستایشگر باربد به محمدرضا شجریان - خبرگزاری شبستان ، رسانه حوزه دین ، فرهنگ و اندیشه|url=http://shabestan.ir/mobile/detail/news/683778|access-date=2021-10-28|website=shabestan.ir}}</ref> Amir Abbas Golab and Reza Tajbakhsh sang together at the [[Fajr Music Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=همخوانی امیر عباس گلاب و رضا تاجبخش در جشنواره موسیقی فجر|url=https://www.vidbid.ir/video/281069/%D9%87%D9%85%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%A7%D9%85%DB%8C%D8%B1-%D8%B9%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B3-%DA%AF%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%A8-%D9%88-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%AC%D8%B4%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C-%D9%81%D8%AC%D8%B1|access-date=2021-10-28|website=رسانه ویدبید - بهترین ویدئو های روز|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=roohmusic|date=2019-02-16|title=همخوانی امیر عباس گلاب و رضا تاجبخش در جشنواره موسیقی فجر|url=https://roohmusic.ir/video/3c9h/همخوانی-امیر-عباس-گلاب-و-رضا-تاجبخش-در-جشنواره-موسیقی-فجر/|access-date=2021-10-28|website=آهنگ های جدید و قدیمی ایرانی بهترین سایت دانلود موزیک RoohMusic|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-02-16|title=همخوانی امیر عباس گلاب و رضا تاجبخش در جشنواره موسیقی فجر|url=https://baamaagroup.ir/fajr-milad-26bahman/|access-date=2021-10-28|website=موسسه فرهنگی هنری باما|language=fa-IR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=پاپ‌خوان‌ها در جشنواره موسیقی فجر چه می‌خوانند؟ {{!}} اقتصاد آنلاین|url=https://www.eghtesadonline.com/بخش-%D8%B9%D9%85%D9%88%D9%85%DB%8C-30/332581-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%87%D8%A7-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%AC%D8%B4%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C-%D9%81%D8%AC%D8%B1-%DA%86%D9%87-%D9%85%DB%8C-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%86%D8%AF|access-date=2021-10-28|website=www.eghtesadonline.com|language=fa}}</ref> Reza Tajbakhsh also participated in this [[Fajr Music Festival]] as the conductor of [[Babak Jahanbakhsh]] Orchestra.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-06-24|title=سوپرایز بابک جهانبخش در جشنواره موسیقی فجر + تصاویر|url=https://mag.tanposh-parsi.com/babak-jahanbakhsh-surprise-at-fajr-music-festival-pictures/|access-date=2021-10-28|website=مجله پارسی|language=fa-IR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=سوپرایز بابک جهانبخش در جشنواره موسیقی فجر + تصاویر|url=https://namnak.com/بابک-جهانبخش-در-جشنواره-موسیقی-فجر.p27254|access-date=2021-10-28|website=نمناک|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2011-02-26|title=نوای پایانی جشنواره بیست و ششم فجر از برج میلاد برخواست|url=https://www.cinemapress.ir/news/17349/نوای-پایانی-جشنواره-بیست-و-ششم-فجر-از-برج-میلاد-برخواست|access-date=2021-10-28|website=اخبار سینمای ایران و جهان - سینماپرس|language=fa}}</ref>
=== Pop Romance Concert === In the year 2018, a number of pop singers led by Reza Tajbakhsh Orchestra performed the concert "Pop Romance" in the hall of the Ministry of Interior.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-04-15|title=شش خواننده کنسرت «عاشقانه های پاپ» را برگزار می کنند|url=https://www.mehrnews.com/news/4271122/شش-خواننده-کنسرت-عاشقانه-های-پاپ-را-برگزار-می-کنند|access-date=2021-10-28|website=خبرگزاری مهر {{!}} اخبار ایران و جهان {{!}} Mehr News Agency|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=رضا تاجبخش با شش خواننده «عاشقانه‌های پاپ» را برگزار می‌کند|url=https://www.ilna.news/بخش-%D9%81%D8%B1%D9%87%D9%86%DA%AF-%D9%87%D9%86%D8%B1-6/614896-%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B4-%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%B4%D8%B4-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%87-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%B1%DA%AF%D8%B2%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%85%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%AF|access-date=2021-10-28|website=خبرگزاری ایلنا|language=fa}}</ref> "Pop Romance" concert with the joint performance of a number of well-known pop singers, including Roozbeh Nematollahi, Amir Abbas Golab, [[Reza Sadeghi]], Hamid Hami, Mehdi Yarahi and Siamak Abbasi on May 14 and 15, led and arranged by Reza Tajbakhsh in the hall [[Ministry of Interior Hall]] was held.<ref>{{Cite web|last=فرهنگی|first=سایت خبری تحلیلی تابناک|date=۱۳۹۷/۰۱/۲۶ - ۱۷:۰۶|title=شش خواننده کنسرت «عاشقانه های پاپ» را برگزار می کنند|url=http://tabnakfarhangi.ir/fa/news/9241|access-date=2021-10-28|website=fa|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Citna|date=2018-04-30|title=این مهم‌ترین کنسرت پاپ بعد از انقلاب است|url=https://www.citna.ir/different/212318/%D8%A7%DB%8C%D9%86-%D9%85%D9%87%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%DB%8C%D9%86-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%AA-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%A8%D8%B9%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D8%B2-%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%82%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA|access-date=2021-10-28|website=سیتنا|language=fa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=عاشقانه های پاپ در تالار وزارت کشور اجرا می شود|url=https://www.sornakhabar.com/بخش-%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B1-3/20040-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D9%BE-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D9%88%D8%B2%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AA|access-date=2021-10-28|website=سرنا خبر - رسانه فرهنگ و هنر|language=fa}}</ref>

colspan="4" style="background:#B0C4DE;" |{{Interlanguage link multi|L'ivrogne Et L'amoureux|fa|مست و عاشق}} (Unofficial, Released: 2020)<ref>{{Citation|title=L'ivrogne et l'amoureux by Reza Tajbakhsh|date=2020-11-25|url=https://music.apple.com/my/album/livrogne-et-lamoureux/1578127213|language=en-GB|access-date=2021-10-23}}</ref> |- style="text-align:center;" !No. !Title !Native !Lyrics |- |01 |L'ivrogne Et L'amoureux |{{lang|fa|مست و عشق}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |02 |O'cheikh |{{lang|fa|اوچیخ}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |03 |Ivre du vin des mages |{{lang|fa|مست از شراب مجوس}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |04 |Echanson |{{lang|fa|ایکانسون}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |05 |How long to worry |{{lang|fa|تا کی باید نگران بود}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |06 |Ne te chagrine pas |{{lang|fa|غصه نخور}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |07 |Seize the moment |{{lang|fa|به دست گرفتن لحظه ای}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |- |08 |Sans nous trouver |{{lang|fa|بی آنکه ما را پیدا کند}} |Reza Tajbakhsh |} <small><sup>†</sup>: The songs that Reza Tajbakhsh publishes for free in digital music stores with his label Band, [[Zarbofoot]], with the official permission of [[Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance|Ershad]], and is available on the Internet.</small>
=== Albums ===
* ''2019: Plastic Garden <ref>{{Cite web|title=Plastic Garden (with Reza Tajbakhsh)|url=https://www.lyrics.com.es/at/music/1488174140/-|url-status=live|access-date=2021-10-23|website=Lyrics|language=de-AT}}</ref>'' * ''2018: Your Last Smile (Piano Solo) <ref>{{Citation|last=Behdad Bahrami & Reza Tajbakhsh|title=Your Last Smile|url=https://www.amazon.com/Your-Last-Smile-Piano-Solo/dp/B005HAODWY|access-date=2021-10-23}}</ref>'' * ''2016: L'ivrogne Et L'amoureux <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://music.amazon.com/albums/B09B5MQ9ZW|access-date=2021-10-23|website=music.amazon.com}}</ref>''
=== Singles === {{Div col|colwidth=45em}} * 01: The Best Song Of The Universe * 02: Vietnam Rain * 03: 30 Days * 04: If * 05: Mibakhshamet * 06: Sahel * 07: The Best Song Of The Universe (remix) * 08: Kavir * 09: The Story Of You And I * 10: Nagahan Bi To * 11: Donbalet Miam * 12: Donbalet Miam(acoustic version) {{div col end}}
== Awards and nominations == Below you can see the list of awards and nominations of Reza Tajbakhsh {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" |Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" !Award !Year !Category !Result !Ref |- |[[Musicema Awards]] |2012 |Best Arranger of the Year |{{won}} |<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-01-02|title=بیوگرافی رضا تاجبخش و داستان زندگی شخصی همراه با عکس ها و تصاویر اینستاگرام|url=https://www.starbino.com/30973/بیوگرافی-رضا-تاجبخش.html|access-date=2021-10-28|website=مجله اینترنتی استاربینو|language=fa-IR}}</ref> |- |[[Musicema Awards]] |2013 |Best Composer of the Year |{{won}} |<ref>{{Cite web|title=لیست کامل نامزد های بخش های مختلف نظرسنجی بزرگ سایت موسیقی ما|url=https://www.musicema.com/node/179078|access-date=2021-10-22|website=Musicema.com|language=fa}}</ref> |- |[[Musicema Awards]] |2014 |Best Producer of the Year |{{won}} |<ref>{{Citation|title=فیلم اهدای جایزه بهترین تنظیم کننده سال به رضا تاجبخش - 1393|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GbTLNtDsnCA|language=en|access-date=2021-10-28}}</ref> |- |[[Musicema Awards]] |2019 |Best Producer of the Year |{{won}} |<ref>{{Cite web|title=برندگان جشن «موسیقی ما» با حضور چهره های سرشناس|url=https://seemorgh.com/culture/music/419971-%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AC%D8%B4%D9%86-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%82%DB%8C-%D9%85%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%AD%D8%B6%D9%88%D8%B1-%DA%86%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B4%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B3/|access-date=2021-10-28|website=سیمرغ|language=fa-ir}}</ref> |- |[[Musicema Awards]] |2020 |Best Musician of the Year |{{nom}} | |}

creating page
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Yoon Sang-won | native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|ko-Hang|윤상원}} ({{lang|ko-Hant|尹祥源}})}} | image = | imagesize = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1950|8|19}} | birth_place = [[Gwangju]], South Korea | death_date = {{Death date and age|1980|5|27|1950|8|19}} | death_place = [[Gwangju]], South Korea | years_active = | occupation = activist | spouse = }} '''Yoon Sang-won''' ({{korean|hangul=윤상원||hanja=尹祥源}}; 19 August 1950{{spaced ndash}}27 May 1980) was a [[South Korea]]n activist and spokesperson for the citizen's militia during the [[Gwangju Uprising|1980 Gwangju Democratization Movement]].<ref name="Lee interview">{{cite news |last1=Jung |first1=Dae-ha |title=[Interview] Honoring the life of Yoon Sang-won, activist who died for democracy |url=https://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/945421.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |agency=hani.co.kr |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=18 May 2020}}</ref>. Yoon was killed on the last day of the uprising and has since become a symbol in South Korea as a martyr for the [[democratization]] movement.<ref name="Katsiaficas">{{cite news |last1=Katsiaficas |first1=George |title=[Column] Remembering Yoon Sang-won |url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/english_editorials/796809.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |agency=hani.co.kr |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=30 May 2017}}</ref>
==Biography== [[File:Gwangju Jeollanam-do office building1.jpg|thumb|The former [[South Jeolla]] Provincial Office where Joon and others were killed on May 27, 1980.]] Yoon Sang-won was born in [[Gwangsan District]], [[Gwangju]], and attended [[Chonnam National University]] in the 1970s. Opposed to the military dictarship under [[Park Chung-hee]], Yoon quit his job at a bank in 1978 to focus on activism.<ref name="Lee interview" /> Yoon worked on organizing labour groups and helped form the National Democratic Workers’ League on May 1, 1980. On May 18 of that year, a [[Gwangju Uprising|citizen's uprising]] against military rule broke out in Gwangju and Yoon quickly became the leading spokesperson of the organizing Democratic Struggle Committee. As martial law forces violently suppressed the uprising, the armed resistance intensified. Yoon and the remaining militia members took up residence in the main building of the {{ill|Jeonnam Provincial Office|ko|광주_전라남도청_구_본관}} which was turned into the ''de facto'' headquarters of the resistance.<ref name="Lee interview" /> The protesters were able to fortify and hold the building until May 27 when it was stormed by martial law forces. Yoon was killed in the early morning making a last stand to defend the building.<ref name="kt">{{cite news |last1=Kim |first1=Jin-hyun |title=Yoon Sang-won and Gwangju May 18 Uprising |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2016/04/162_179069.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |agency=koreatimes.co.kr |publisher=The Korea Times |date=17 May 2015}}</ref> The Gwangju Democratization Movement ended that day, but it was seen as a precursor to the 1987 [[June Struggle]] that led to the country's first free and democratic [[1987 South Korean presidential election|elections later that year]] within the wider democratization movement known as [[minjung]].
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{short description|American college football season}} {{Infobox college sports team season | year = 1995 | team = Findlay Oilers | sport = football | image = | image_size = | conference = [[Mid-States Football Association]] | short_conf = MSFA | record = 10–1–2 | conf_record = 4–1 | head_coach = [[Dick Strahm]] | hc_year = 23rd | captain = | stadium = | champion = NAIA national co-champion
MSFA co-champion | bowl = [[NAIA Football National Championship|NAIA Division II Championship Game]] | bowl_result = T 21–21 vs. {{cfb link|year=1995|team=Central Washington Wildcats|title=Central Washington}} }} {{1995 Mid-States Football Association standings}} The '''1995 Findlay Oilers football team''' was an [[American football]] team that represented the [[University of Findlay]] as a member of the [[Mid-States Football Association]] (MSFA) during the [[1995 NAIA Division II football season]]. In their 23rd season under head coach [[Dick Strahm]], the Oilers compiled a perfect 10–1–2 record (4–1 against conference opponents), outscored opponents by a total of 454 to 114, and was the NAIA Division II national championship, tying with {{cfb link|year=1995|team=Central Washington Wildcats|title=Central Washington}}, 21–21, in the [[NAIA Football National Championship|NAIA Division II Championship Game]].{{cite web|title=The University of Findlay Oilers Football Media Guide 2011|publisher=University of Findlay|year=2011|page=65|url=https://issuu.com/findlay/docs/athletics_2011_football_mediaguide}} ==Schedule== {{CFB schedule | attend = y | source = y | ||Trinity International|||L 7-14|| | ||Westminster|||T 3-3|| | ||Lindenwood|||W 63-9|| | ||Olivet Nazarene|||W 42-10|| | ||Iowa Wesleyan|||W 49-14|| | ||St. Xavier|||W 56-0|| | ||Tiffin|||W 42-0|| | ||Urbana|||W 37-3|| | ||Taylor|||W 35-6|| | ||Pacific Lutheran|| (NAIA DII championship series)|W 21-14|| | ||Malone|| (NAIA DII quarterfinal)|W 15-7|| | ||Lambuth|| (NAIA DII semifinal)|W 63-13|| |December 16|at|{{cfb link|year=1995|team=Central Washington Wildcats|title=Central Washington}}||[[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma, WA]] (NAIA DII Championship Game)|T 21-21|5,628|{{cite news|title=CWU, Findlay unhappy with deadlock: NAIA Division II title is shared for the third time since 1981|newspaper=The Spokesman Review|date=December 17, 1995|page=C4|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/88169493/cwu-findlay-unhappy-with-deadlock/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{NAIA football national champion navbox}} [[Category:1995 NAIA football season|Findlay Oilers]] [[Category:Findlay Oilers football seasons]] [[Category:NAIA Football National Champions]] [[Category:1995 in sports in Ohio|Findlay Oilers football]]

revision.text:
{{AfC submission|t||ts=20211101201601|u=CT55555|ns=118|demo=}}<!-- Important, do not remove this line before article has been created. -->
'''Nnaemeka Ikegwuonu''' is a Nigerian entrepreneur, CEO<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Rebecca|first=Cairns|title=ColdHubs: How solar-powered cold storage is keeping food fresh in Nigeria|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/23/africa/coldhubs-nigeria-food-supply-chain-hnk-spc-intl/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-11-01|website=CNN}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|last=Yen.com.gh|date=2020-08-19|title=Talented African man invents giant solar-powered refrigerators to help farmers|url=https://yen.com.gh/167277-genius-african-man-invents-giant-solar-powered-refrigerators-farmers-photos.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Yen.com.gh - Ghana news.|language=en}}</ref> and former farmer and radio broadcaster.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|last=Monks|first=By Kieron|date=2015-12-22|title=A radio show host may have fixed Nigeria's worst problem|url=https://www.cnn.com/2015/12/22/africa/cold-hubs/index.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=CNN|language=en}}</ref>
== Early Life == Ikegwuonu is from [[Imo State]], Nigeria<ref name=":3" />. After receiving his education in Europe he returned to Nigeria.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Welle (www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche|title=The 'Global Diplomacy Lab' tackles migration {{!}} DW {{!}} 07.11.2015|url=https://www.dw.com/en/the-global-diplomacy-lab-tackles-migration/a-18834238|access-date=2021-11-01|website=DW.COM|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Career ==
=== Farming === Ikegwuonu was a farmer in Imo State, Nigeria.<ref name=":3" />
=== Smallholders Foundation === In 2003, aged 21, he founded the Smallholders Foundation<ref>{{Cite web|date=2017-12-28|title=How the sun's rays can keep food chilled: fighting waste in Africa|url=http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/dec/28/fighting-food-waste-in-africa|access-date=2021-11-01|website=the Guardian|language=en}}</ref> an interactive radio show to get information to rural Nigerian farmers, that grew to have an audience of over two million listeners.<ref name=":0" />
=== ColdHubs === Following a 2012 trip to [[Dresden]], where he met with scientists to discuss the design of a cold storage system,<ref name=":3" /> Ikegwuonu launched [https://www.coldhubs.com/ ColdHubs], 2015.<ref name=":1" />
As the CEO of ColdHubs, Ikegwuonu started a model of selling solar-powered refrigeration, rented to farmers and fishers by create.<ref name=":1" /> ColdHubs increased the shelf life of perishable food, reducing food waste and increasing food security.<ref name=":1" />
== Awards == Ikegwuonu is a [https://www.rolex.org/rolex-awards Rolex Awards] Laureate<ref name=":1" /> and has won over 24 awards<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Farming by radio - Rolex Awards|url=https://www.rolex.org/rolex-awards/applied-technology/nnaemeka-ikegwuonu|access-date=2021-11-01|website=rolex.org|language=en}}</ref> including:
* [[Africa Food Prize|Yara Prize for Green Revolution in Africa]] (now known as the [[Africa Food Prize]])<ref name=":0" /> *[https://ayute.africa/ AYuTe Africa Challenge]<ref name=":1" /> *2020 Waislitz Global Citizen Disruptor Award winner<ref>{{Cite web|title=Apply Now for the 2021 Waislitz Global Citizen Awards|url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/content/apply-for-2021-waislitz-global-citizen-awards/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Global Citizen|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> == References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}

revision.text:
meetup generic form {{Wikipedia:Meetup/Black Lunch Table/Tab header}} [[File:Black Lunch Table logo.png|frameless|right]] {{Infobox | title = '''Black Lunch Table
@ LOCATION XXX''' | image = | caption = | alt = | headerstyle = background:#ccf; | labelstyle = background:#ddf; | header1 = When and Where | label2 = Date: | data2 = day, month, 2021 | label3 = Time: | data3 = Am/ PM timezone | label4 = Address: | data4 = online: bit (dot) ly/WIKIBLT
| label5 = | data5 = }} {{Meetupsig}} == Event description == The '''Black Lunch Table (BLT)''' will host an online edit-a-thon that focuses on important but underrepresented Black visual artists, curators, and art workers on '''DAY, MONTH NUMBER, 2021 at 12 AM/PM TIMEZONE'''. An overview of Wiki basics, an introduction to the Wikimedia Community, and how to update and edit articles will be held at the beginning of the session. No specialized knowledge of the subject or Wikipedia editing experience required and help will be available throughout the event. The event is free and open to all. == Details and Agenda == '''Date:''' Saturday, February 6, 2021 '''Time:''' 12:30-3:30pm CST '''Location:''' Online @ bit (dot) ly/WIKIBLT
'''Who should attend:''' Artists, historians, students, photographers, teachers, writers, journalists, curators, the curious... '''What to Bring:''' Your laptop and a friend!
''Agenda:'' * Introduction * Presentation /Wiki Overview * Editing time / Questions * Goals: Create a user account (if new to Wikipedia), create user page with at least one sentence, sign up for edit-a-thon on this Wikipedia Meetup page, make at least one edit to a Wikipedia page * [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1ypAmHBf3-n7P8pPI5h6WpDYWQNS7kIewl7WCvV4p9CQ/edit#slide=id.p1 '''BLT Wiki onboarding presentation'''] * '''Etherpad''':[https://etherpad.wikimedia.org/p/BlackLunchTable-Apr BlackLunchTable] - Keep track of live editing during our session * [[Wikipedia:Meetup/Black_Lunch_Table/Resources|'''Resources and How-to's''']] == About Black Lunch Table == [http://www.theblacklunchtable.com Black Lunch Table (BLT)]is a nonprofit organization and sixteen-year ongoing artist collaboration.BLT’s primary aim has been the production of discursive sites, wherein cultural producers engage in dialogue on a variety of critical issues. Black Lunch Table Wikimedians mobilize the creation and improvement of a specific set of Wikipedia articles that pertain to the lives and works of Black artists. In the field of mainstream contemporary art, Black artists are still marginalized within our field. Wikipedia estimates that 77% of their editors are white and 91% of their editors are men. Our work shifts this demographic and empowers people to write their own history. Our sessions and events, including BLT Photobooth and edit-a-thons, equip new editors with the skills and resources to create, update, and improve Wikipedia articles and encourages existing editors to focus on Wikipedia knowledge gaps. {{meetup}} == Articles and Artists to edit == Black Lunch Table's task list is made up of Black visual artists who are under-represented on Wikipedia. We welcome additions to our list so long as they are within our scope. We encourage editors to suggest artists ''who do not have a page'' or ''whose page is a stub'' over adding an artist who already has a substantial page and presence. Please always defer to Wikipedia's NOTABILTY guidelines for new pages. [[Wikipedia:Meetup/Black_Lunch_Table/Lists_of_Articles|'''''BLT's Main Task List''''']] ==Artists associated with LOCATION== Please suggest specific artists who are notable BlackXXXXX who need their article created or whose existing article needs improvement. Be sure they qualify according to Wikipedia's NOTABILITY guidelines, thanks! *JOE DOE ==Wikidata Query== == Wikicommons Photos == Photographs and images are an important part of Wiki as well. If you are interested in uploading images use the below resources to learn how and make sure you have the right licensing for all images uploaded. * [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Public_Art/Image_guide|Wiki Image Guide] * [https://whoseknowledge.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/How-to-find-free-images.pdf Where to find them.] * [https://whoseknowledge.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Adding-images-to-Wikimedia-Commons-and-Wikipedia_-dos-and-donts.pdf Dos and Donts] * [https://whoseknowledge.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/How-to-Ask-for-Image-Donations.pdf Asking an artist for images.] ==Attendees== {{Help navigation}} {{Wikipedia policies and guidelines}}

{{Short description|Azerbaijani volleyball player}} {{Infobox volleyball biography|name=Ilhama Aliyeva|spike=215 cm|caption=|fullname=|nickname=|nationality={{AZE}}|birth_date={{birth date and age|1999|4|9|df=y}}|birth_place=|hometown=|height={{convert|1.7|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}}|weight={{convert|59|kg|lb|abbr=on}}|image=|college=|block=205 cm|position=Outside spiker|currentclub=|currentnumber=|years=|teams=|nationalyears=2018-present|nationalteam={{flagicon|Azerbaijan}} [[Azerbaijan women's national volleyball team|Azerbaijan]]|medaltemplates=<!-- See [[Template:MedalSport]] -->|medaltemplates-expand=set to "yes" to auto-expand medaltemplates section|updated=}}
'''Ilhama Aliyeva''' (born {{birth date|1999|4|9|df=yes}}) is an [[Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani]] [[volleyball]] player.
She competed at the [[2021 Women's European Volleyball Championship]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Teams {{!}} EuroVolley|url=https://eurovolley.cev.eu/en/women/teams/team/11830-azerbaijan|access-date=2021-11-01|website=eurovolley.cev.eu}}</ref>
In 2017, she competed in Beach volleyball with [[Irina Abbaszade]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ilhama Aliyeva Azerbaijan|url=http://www.bvbinfo.com/player.asp?ID=17728|url-status=live|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.bvbinfo.com}}</ref> She played for Lokomotiv Baku, and Murov VC.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Ilhama Aliyeva » clubs :|url=https://women.volleybox.net/ilhama-aliyeva-p19731/clubs|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Women Volleybox|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Women {{!}} CEV|url=https://www.cev.eu/national-team/european-league/european-golden-league/women/team/12108-azerbaijan/player/65122-aliyeva-ilhama|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.cev.eu}}</ref>
