revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = Upcoming Rosalía album | type = studio album | artist = [[Rosalía (singer)|Rosalía]] | cover = | border = | alt = | released = TBA | recorded = 2019–2021 | studio = | genre = | length = | label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]] | producer = | prev_title = [[El mal querer|El Mal Querer]] | prev_year = 2018 | year = TBA | next_title = | next_year = | misc = }}
The '''upcoming studio album''' by Spanish singer [[Rosalía (singer)|Rosalía]], her third, is scheduled to be released through [[Columbia Records]].
== Background and recording == In November 2018, Rosalía released her second studio album ''[[El mal querer|El Mal Querer]]'' to critical acclaim and commercial succes. The album, inspired by the ''[[Romance of Flamenca]]'', a 13th-centrury annonymous Occitan novel, launched the singer's career to another level.<ref>{{Cite web|last=País|first=Ediciones El|date=2019-09-04|title=La novela medieval que inspiró 'El mal querer' de Rosalía renace en las librerías|url=https://verne.elpais.com/verne/2019/09/04/articulo/1567594882_786552.html|access-date=2020-07-02|website=Verne|language=es}}</ref> By twisting [[flamenco music]] and giving it a more modern interpretations, Rosalía became very popular among critics and general public mainly in selected parts of Europe and Latin America. ''El Mal Querer'' was listed in many year-end publications as well as in ''[[Rolling Stone]]''<nowiki/>'s [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|500 Greatest Albums of All Time]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=#315 Rosalía, 'El Mal Querer' (2018)|url=https://www.rs500albums.com/350-301/315|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Rolling Stone 500 Greatest Albums Of All Time|language=en-US}}</ref>
Recording sessions for the singer's next project began in [[Los Angeles]] as early as 2019 and, in October of that year, Rosalía confirmed to ''[[W Magazine|W]]'' that her new album would be released in 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rosalía Is the Future of Pop Music|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/rosalia-music-cover-story-interview/|access-date=2020-07-03|website=W Magazine {{!}} Women's Fashion & Celebrity News|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=LOS40|date=2019-10-01|title=Rosalía desvela cuando saldrá su próximo disco|url=https://los40.com/los40/2019/10/01/musica/1569917125_264720.html|access-date=2020-07-03|website=LOS40|language=es}}</ref> Nevertheless, while on tour in 2019, Rosalía released a collection of singles instead. In March, the first of eight singles, "[[Con Altura]]", featuring [[J Balvin]] and [[El Guincho]] was released on digital platforms.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-04-01|title=¿Qué críticas ha generado la nueva canción de Rosalía?|url=https://us.hola.com/actualidad/20190401139835/rosalia-balvin-opiniones-nuevo-single/|access-date=2019-10-18|website=HOLA USA}}</ref> The track, which includes the signature lyric 'La Rosalía', topped the charts in Argentina, Venezuela, Spain and Colombia among others and was the second most-watched music video released in 2019 on [[YouTube]] and the most-watched female music video as well as the first on the list by a Spanish language song.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-07-08|title=Rosalía’s ‘Con Altura’ the highest viewed video by a female artist this year|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/rosalias-con-altura-the-highest-viewed-video-by-a-female-artist-this-year/|access-date=2020-07-02|website=Tone Deaf|language=en-AU}}</ref> The song won the [[Latin Grammy Award|Latin Grammy award]] for [[Latin Grammy Award for Best Urban Song|Best Urban Song]] and two [[MTV Video Music Award|MTV Video Music Awards]]. May saw the release of "[[Aute Cuture]]" whereas "[[Milionària]]" and "[[Dios nos libre del dinero|Dios Nos Libre del Dinero]]" were released in July. In August, a collaboration with [[Ozuna (singer)|Ozuna]], "[[Yo x Ti, Tu x Mi]]", was released.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-08-26|title=Rosalia & Ozuna's Performance At The 2019 MTV VMAs: Watch|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/awards/8528405/rosalia-ozuna-performance-2019-mtv-vmas-video|access-date=2020-07-02|website=Billboard}}</ref> The singer continued releasing independent tracks such as "[[A Palé]]", "[[Dolerme]]" and "[[Juro Que]]".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Aswad|first=Jem|last2=Aswad|first2=Jem|date=2019-11-07|title=Rosalia Drops Hard-Hitting New Song and Video, ‘A Pale’|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/rosalia-drops-hard-hitting-new-song-and-video-a-pale-1203397643/|access-date=2020-07-02|website=Variety|language=en}}</ref> Rosalía also collaborated twice with [[Travis Scott]]; firstly on the remix of his track "[[Highest in the Room]]" alongside [[Lil Baby]] and then on "[[TKN (song)|TKN]]".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Wang|first=Steffanee|title=Rosalía Ad-Libs On Travis Scott's "Highest In The Room" Remix|url=https://www.nylon.com/rosalia-travis-scott-highest-in-the-room-remix|access-date=2020-07-02|website=Nylon|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-10|title=Rosalia Makes Hot 100 Debut, Bows at No. 2 on Hot Latin Songs With 'TKN'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/9399656/rosalia-travis-scott-tkn-hot-100-hot-latin-songs|access-date=2020-07-03|website=Billboard}}</ref>
When Dutch radio station [[3VOOR12]] asked the singer through a ''[[Zoom Video Communications|Zoom]]'' press conference about a possible single [[Compilation album|compilation]] or [[box set]], Rosalía expressed total rejection to the idea explaining that "I don't really enjoy singles that are collections of singles. I usually enjoy records that tell a story and that are alive and a lot of thinking. I am totally against the first idea".<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Rosalía denkt niet in singles maar in projecten|url=https://3voor12.vpro.nl/update~a5ab69d2-1c4f-4ec2-82cb-98ab87022e3a~rosal%C3%ADa-denkt-niet-in-singles-maar-in-projecten~.html|access-date=2020-07-02|website=3voor12|language=nl}}</ref> She also stated that she was "trying really hard to release a new project this year but all of the singles you've heard so far won't be included. As a musician I feel the responsibility to release a cohesive album, one that makes sense; one in where the songs are linked and share an essence. In conclusion, I want to make an album that makes sense as you listen to it as a whole". She also told [[La Repubblica|''La Repubblica'']] and [[El Universal (Mexico City)|''El Universal'']] that this new project will not have any collaboration despite teasing a duet with [[Arca (musician)|Arca]] shortly after and being spotted with musicians like [[Playboi Carti]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rosalía pide visibilizar a las mujeres|url=https://www.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/rosalia-pide-visibilizar-las-mujeres|access-date=2020-07-03|website=www.eluniversal.com.mx}}</ref> Rosalía was also seen in the recording studio with [[Michael Uzowuru]] and [[Mike Dean (record producer)|Mike Dean]] among others.<ref>{{Cite web|last=LOS40|date=2021-04-14|title=Rosalía pierde la noción del tiempo trabajando en su nueva música: “No sé si es domingo o martes”|url=https://los40.com/los40/2021/04/14/musica/1618412288_505210.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=LOS40|language=es}}</ref> In late 2020, [[Pharrell Williams]] stated that he was "blown away by its title" and was "honoured to be a part of it”.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Pharrell discusses Rosalía’s new album, says he’s “honoured to be a part of it”|url=https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/news/latest-news/pharrell-discusses-rosalias-new-album-says-hes-honoured-to-be-a-part-of-it|access-date=2021-11-01|website=The Line of Best Fit|language=en}}</ref>
During 2021, Rosalía kept teasing her upcoming studio album yet released more independent singles such as "[[Lo Vas a Olvidar]]" alongside [[Billie Eilish]] for ''[[Euphoria (American TV series)|Euphoria]]'', and "[[Linda (Tokischa and Rosalía song)|Linda]]" with [[Tokischa]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Billie Eilish and Rosalía’s Highly Anticipated Collab 'Lo Vas a Olvidar' Is Dropping This Week|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/9513330/billie-eilish-rosalia-lo-vas-a-olvidar-euphoria-new-song-teaser|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Billboard|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=First Stream Latin: Randy's Album, Anitta & Saweetie's Collab, Plus More New Music|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/latin/9646084/first-stream-latin-randy-anitta-saweetie|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Billboard|language=en}}</ref> In May, talent manager Rebecca León confirmed that Rosalía wouldn't release an album in 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rodríguez|first=Por Christian|date=2021-05-06|title=Lo sentimos: Rosalía no lanzará este año su nuevo disco|url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/es/famosos/musica/a36352751/rosalia-nuevo-disco-2021/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Cosmopolitan|language=es-ES}}</ref> In August, Rosalía revealed to [[Santiago Matías]] that the album "was already taking shape but I don't know how many songs it'll have".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Moda|first=S.|date=2021-08-12|title=Rosalía en una radio dominicana: "Me desenamoro muy fácilmente" {{!}} Celebrities, Vips|url=https://smoda.elpais.com/celebrities/vips/rosalia-entrevista-feminismo-j-balvin-amor-alofoke/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=S Moda EL PAÍS|language=es}}</ref> Three months later, the singer teased on [[TikTok]] that the project will be released "soon" and premiered 30 seconds of an unreleased track believed to be the lead single.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-10-12|title=It Seems Rosalía is Dropping A Bachata Track — & People Have Thoughts|url=https://remezcla.com/music/rosalia-bachata-response-tiktok/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Remezcla|language=en-US}}</ref> During a fan meet and greet in Mexico in partnership with [[Exa FM]], Rosalía revealed that her new album will be "very different and will be enjoyed" by her fans. She also revealed that the lead single would be released in November.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-10-20|title=¡Paren todo porque Rosalía anda de paseo en CDMX y echó taco en Orinoco!|url=https://www.sopitas.com/musica/rosalia-en-cdmx-tacos-orinoco-el-parnita-colonia-roma-videos-fotos/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Sopitas.com|language=en}}</ref>
== Promotion ==
=== Tour === In October 2021, in the mark of the BIME Pro music conference, tour manager Agustín Boffi revealed that Rosalía will embark on a "would tour in 2022" that has been being prepared "for over a year". Boffi also revealed that the tour crew will be expanded to "over 150 people" compared to the 40 people that were working on [[El Mal Querer Tour|her previous concert cycle]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Deia|title=Agustín Boffi: "Lleva más de un año preparar una gira internacional como la de Rosalía"|url=https://www.deia.eus/cultura/2021/10/27/agustin-boffi-lleva-ano-preparar/1162458.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.deia.eus|language=es}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{short description|American politician}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Alexa Avilés | state_assembly = | district = | term_start = | term_end = | predecessor = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | profession = politician, non-profit administration | spouse = Frankie Avilés | children = 2 | education = [[Columbia University]], [[Baruch College]] | residence = [[Sunset Park, Brooklyn|Sunset Park]], [[Brooklyn]] | website = {{url|https://www.alexaforcouncil.com/|Campaign website}} | image = }} '''Alexa Avilés''' is an American politician, community activist, and non-profit manager from [[New York City]]. She is the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee for the [[New York City's 38th City Council district|38th district]] of the [[New York City Council]] – tantamount to election in the heavily Democratic district,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/ny-oped-how-local-leaders-are-made-20210624-xfi6cfdxbrf25fo7cux3lmdnoi-story.html|title=How local leaders are made: Looking at the incoming City Council|first=Errol|last=Louis|website=nydailynews.com}}</ref> which covers [[Sunset Park, Brooklyn|Sunset Park]] along [[Brooklyn]]'s western shoreline, also covering [[Red Hook, Brooklyn|Red Hook]], [[Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn|Greenwood Heights]], and small parts of [[Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn|Windsor Terrace]], [[Dyker Heights, Brooklyn|Dyker Heights]], and [[Borough Park, Brooklyn|Borough Park]] neighborhoods in western [[Brooklyn]]. Avilés worked in the non-profit sector served as president of the [[parent-teacher association]] and a member of [[Brooklyn Community Board 7]].
==Early life and education== Avilés was born in Puerto Rico, and raised in [[East New York]].<ref name="C&S">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cityandstateny.com/personality/2021/07/alexa-aviles-big-table-socialist/183780/|title=Alexa Avilés is a big-table socialist|website=City & State NY}}</ref><ref name="CityLimits">{{Cite web|url=https://citylimits.org/2021/04/23/opinion-why-public-education-advocates-must-stand-with-nycs-grad-student-workers/|title=Opinion: Why Public Education Advocates Must Stand With NYC's Grad Student Workers|date=April 23, 2021|website=City Limits}}</ref> She was the youngest of seven children to a substance abuse counselor mother, and the first in her family to attend college.<ref name="About">{{Cite web|url=https://www.alexaforcouncil.com/about-alexa-aviles|title=About Alexa|website=Alexa Avilés for City Council}}</ref> She graduated [[Columbia University]] in 1995, and received a master's degree from [[CUNY]]'s [[Baruch College]] [[Marxe School of Public and International Affairs|School of Public and International Affairs]].<ref name="CityLimits"/> She is a [[National Urban Fellow]] and an alumna of [[A Better Chance]].<ref name="DYCD">{{Cite web|url=https://www1.nyc.gov/site/dycd/involved/boards-and-councils/yb-members.page|title=Youth Board Members - DYCD|website=www1.nyc.gov}}</ref>
==Career== Her first job began as internship in college and then continued after graduation, at a philanthropy that provided environmental grants in under-served communities in Mississippi, and from there she branched out to work in [[reproductive rights]] and justice drives for native communities.<ref name="Star-Revue">{{Cite web|url=http://www.star-revue.com/alexa-aviles-is-running-for-city-council/|title=Alexa Aviles is running for City Council, by Nathan Weiser|date=June 7, 2021}}</ref> She later{{when|date=November 2021}} worked for the Justice, Equality, Human dignity and Tolerance Foundation (JEHT), focused on mass incarceration issues as a program manage, focusing on juvenile decarceration.<ref name="Star-Revue"/><ref name="DYCD"/> She also worked at the Fund of the Four Directions{{when|date=November 2021}}.<ref name="DYCD"/>
Avilés was a program officer and then program director at the Scherman Foundation from 2011 to 2021, working on advocacy for human rights, reproductive rights, and strengthening programs for the arts.<ref name="DYCD"/><ref name="Indy">{{Cite web|url=https://indypendent.org/2021/06/sunset-park-parent-leader-vows-to-bring-social-movements-to-city-council-with-her/|title=Sunset Park Parent Leader Vows to Bring Social Movements to City Council With Her}}</ref>
===Elected office=== In 2021, Avilés defeated five other candidates to win the [[2021 New York City Council election#District 38|Democratic nomination]], and is running in the November general without Republican opposition.<ref name="Ballotpedia">{{Cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Alexa_Aviles|title=Alexa Aviles|website=Ballotpedia}}</ref> She received endorsements from U.S. Senator [[Bernie Sanders]], Congressmembers [[Nydia Velázquez]] and [[Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez]], State Senators [[Julia Salazar]] and [[Jabari Brisport]], Assemblymember [[Marcela Mitaynes]], the [[Working Families Party]], [[United Federation of Teachers]], [[District Council 37]], and other local groups and elected officials.<ref name="Gazette">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gothamgazette.com/city/10553-future-immigrant-communities-brooklyn-city-council-race-cd38|title=Future of Immigrant Communities the Focus of Brooklyn City Council Race|first=Amanda|last=Salazar|website=Gotham Gazette}}</ref><ref name="C&S"/><ref name="Jacobin">{{Cite web|url=https://jacobinmag.com/2021/06/alexa-aviles-interview-new-york-city-council-district-38-south-brooklyn-dsa-for-the-city|title=“The Billionaires Are Nervous. And They Should Be Nervous.”|website=jacobinmag.com}}</ref> In the 5th round of [[Ranked voting|ranked choice voting]], she prevailed over closest candidate Yu Lin 65%-35%.<ref name="Ballotpedia"/>
==Personal life== She lives with her husband, Frankie, and her two daughters in Sunset Park, where she has lived since 2000.<ref name="Gazette"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rednet.socialists.nyc/city-council-candidate-interview-district-38-alexa-aviles/|title=City Council Candidate Interview: District 38, Alexa Avilés|first=Jack|last=Cieslak|date=January 30, 2021}}</ref><ref name="About"/><ref name="Indy"/>
Avilés is a boardmember of the Management Assistance Group, and serves on the Racial Justice Advisory Council of the Brooklyn Community Foundation.<ref name="DYCD"/> She is a member of [[Brooklyn Community Board 7]] and serves as the president of the [[PS 172]] [[parent-teacher association]].<ref name="Jacobin"/><ref name="DYCD"/>
She is a member of the [[Democratic Socialists of America]].<ref name="Indy"/><ref name="C&S"/><ref name="Jacobin"/>
==Election history==
{{Empty section|date=July 2021}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
{{New York City Council}}

revision.text: The Iron Order is a Roblox group dedicated to removing degeneracy out of Roblox. Their main targets are groups, people, or games affiliated with LGBTQ+, furries, BLM, and other types of degeneracy. The group consists of 6 members, 3 of them being soldiers, 2 admins, and the owner. The group has won 3 battles, 2 of them in LGBTQ+ games, and one in a café. They have one loss, that being in "The Streets." The group hosts trainings in multiple games, on some days. The group is based on Nazi Germany, and it is mainly targeted at the Wehrmatch (Nazi Germany Army) and not the ᛋᛋ (The Schutzstaffel). The group has 0 affiliates, and 0 enemys, not including LGBTQ+, furries, or BLM groups. The group leans towards right-winged politics, and fascism. They are not full fascists, but more of a homophobes and right-wingers. The group started in 2020 (Month or day is unknown) and is still active

{{otheruses|Shuklino}} {{short description|Rural locality in Kursk Oblast, Russia}} {{Infobox Russian rural locality |en_name=Shuklino |ru_name=Шуклино |image_skyline= |image_caption= |coordinates = {{coord|51|57|29|N|35|39|34|E|type:city_region:RU|display=title,inline}} |map_label_position=right |image_coa= |coa_caption= |image_flag= |flag_caption= |anthem= |anthem_ref= |holiday= |holiday_ref= |federal_subject=[[Kursk Oblast]] |federal_subject_ref= |adm_data_as_of= |adm_district_jur=[[Fatezhsky District]] |adm_district_jur_ref={{OKATO reference|38 244 876 007}} |adm_selsoviet_type=[[Selsoviet]] |adm_selsoviet_jur=Soldatsky |adm_selsoviet_jur_ref= |adm_ctr_of1= |adm_ctr_of1_ref= |adm_ctr_of2= |adm_ctr_of2_ref= |inhabloc_cat=Rural locality |inhabloc_cat_ref= |inhabloc_type=''Village'' |inhabloc_type_ref= |mun_data_as_of=December 2014 |mun_district_jur=Fatezhsky Municipal District |mun_district_jur_ref=Law #114-OZ |rural_settlement_jur=Soldatsky Selsoviet Rural Settlement |rural_settlement_jur_ref= |mun_admctr_of1= |mun_admctr_of1_ref= |mun_admctr_of2= |mun_admctr_of2_ref= |leader_title= |leader_title_ref= |leader_name= |leader_name_ref= |representative_body= |representative_body_ref= |area_of_what= |area_as_of= |area_km2= |area_km2_ref= |pop_2010census=50 |pop_2010census_ref={{ru-pop-ref|2010Census}} |pop_density= |pop_density_as_of= |pop_density_ref= |pop_latest= |pop_latest_date= |pop_latest_ref= |established_date= |established_title=First mentioned |established_date_ref= |current_cat_date= |current_cat_date_ref= |prev_name1= |prev_name1_date= |prev_name1_ref= |postal_codes=307112 |postal_codes_ref={{cite web|url=https://gdeposylka.ru/courier/russian-post/307112|title=Russian shipment tracking service|publisher=ГдеПосылка.ру|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}} |dialing_codes=47144 |dialing_codes_ref= |website=http://мосолдатский.рф |website_ref= |commonscat= |date=November 2021}} '''Shuklino''' ({{lang-ru|links=no|Шуклино}}) is a [[types of inhabited localities in Russia|rural locality]] ({{Lang-ru|деревня|lit=village}}) in Soldatsky Selsoviet Rural Settlement, [[Fatezhsky District]], [[Kursk Oblast]], [[Russia]]. Population: {{ru-census|p2010=50|p2002=68|p1989=79}} == Geography == The village is located on the Ruda River (a link tributary of the Usozha in the basin of the Svapa), 87 km from the [[Russia–Ukraine border]], 44 km north-west of [[Kursk]], 19 km south-west of the district center – the town [[Fatezh]], 14 km from the selsoviet center – [[Soldatskoye, Fatezhsky District, Kursk Oblast|Soldatskoye]].{{cite web|url=https://publichnaya-kadastrovaya-karta.com/kurskaya/fatezhskij_shuklino?obj=87482|title=Real estate report: Shuklino|publisher=publichnaya-kadastrovaya-karta.com|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}} ; Climate Shuklino has a warm-summer [[humid continental climate]] (''Dfb'' in the [[Köppen climate classification]]).
{{Weather box |location = Shuklino |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan high C = -4.3 |Feb high C = -3.4 |Mar high C = 2.4 |Apr high C = 12.7 |May high C = 19 |Jun high C = 22.3 |Jul high C = 24.9 |Aug high C = 24.2 |Sep high C = 17.8 |Oct high C = 10.2 |Nov high C = 3.1 |Dec high C = -1.4 |year high C = |Jan mean C = -6.3 |Feb mean C = -5.8 |Mar mean C = -1 |Apr mean C = 8 |May mean C = 14.5 |Jun mean C = 18.1 |Jul mean C = 20.7 |Aug mean C = 19.7 |Sep mean C = 13.7 |Oct mean C = 7 |Nov mean C = 1 |Dec mean C = -3.3 |year mean C = |Jan low C = -8.7 |Feb low C = -8.7 |Mar low C = -4.9 |Apr low C = 2.6 |May low C = 9 |Jun low C = 12.9 |Jul low C = 15.7 |Aug low C = 14.7 |Sep low C = 9.6 |Oct low C = 3.9 |Nov low C = -1.3 |Dec low C = -5.4 |year low C = |Jan precipitation mm = 52 |Feb precipitation mm = 45 |Mar precipitation mm = 47 |Apr precipitation mm = 51 |May precipitation mm = 62 |Jun precipitation mm = 73 |Jul precipitation mm = 77 |Aug precipitation mm = 57 |Sep precipitation mm = 60 |Oct precipitation mm = 60 |Nov precipitation mm = 48 |Dec precipitation mm = 50 |year precipitation = |date=November 2021|source=https://en.climate-data.org/asia/russian-federation/kursk-oblast/шуклино-687149/}}
== Transport == Shuklino is located 18 km from the federal route {{Road marker simple|-|M-2|#0090ff|white|-}} [[M2 highway (Russia)|Crimea Highway]] as part of the European route [[European route E105|E105]], 16 km from the road of regional importance {{Road marker simple|-|38K-038|#0090ff|white|-}} (Fatezh – [[Dmitriyev (town)|Dmitriyev]]), 0.5 km from the road of intermunicipal significance {{Road marker simple|-|38Н-679|#0090ff|white|-}} (38K-038 – Soldatskoye – Shuklino),{{cite web|url=https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/w/images/a/ac/38._Перечень_автодорог.pdf|title=Постановление Администрации Курской области от 28.07.2006 N 76 (ред. от 16.09.2020) "Об утверждении Перечня автомобильных дорог общего пользования регионального и межмуниципального значения Курской области" (дата сохранения: 23.01.2021) / Resolution of the Administration of the Kursk Oblast of July 28, 2006 Nr 76 (as amended on September 16, 2020) "On approval of the List of public roads of regional and intermunicipal significance of the Kursk Oblast" (save date: 01/23/2021)|publisher=openstreetmap.org|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}} 24.5 km from the nearest railway halt ''552 km''{{cite web|url=https://railwayz.info/photolines/station/7014|title=о.п. 552 км|publisher=railwayz.info|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}} (railway line Navlya – Lgov-Kiyevsky). The rural locality is situated 48.5 km from [[Kursk Vostochny Airport]], 158 km from [[Belgorod International Airport]] and 246 km from [[Voronezh International Airport|Voronezh Peter the Great Airport]]. ==References== ===Notes=== {{Reflist}} ===Sources=== *{{RussiaAdmMunRef|krs|adm|list}} *{{RussiaAdmMunRef|krs|mun|list0}} {{Rural localities in Fatezhsky District, Kursk oblast}} {{Authority control}} {{KurskOblast-geo-stub}} [[Category:Rural localities in Kursk Oblast]]

revision.comment: Declining submission: v - Submission is improperly sourced and nn - Submission is about a topic not yet shown to meet general notability guidelines (be more specific if possible) ([[WP:AFCH|AFCH]] 0.9.1)
revision.text:
{{AFC submission|d|v|u=WeirdAlboy|ns=118|decliner=Idoghor Melody|declinets=20211101212911|reason2=nn|ts=20211101205329}} <!-- Do not remove this line! -->
The San Marcos creek is a small [[Creek|creek]] in [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County, CA]]. It begins a little before [[Lake San Marcos, California|Lake San Marcos]] and ends in the [[Batiquitos Lagoon]]. It is not free flowing meaning it is [[dammed]]. This creek is mostly [[Fresh water|freshwater]] but is [[Brackish water|brackish]] at it's [[headwaters]].
Similar creeks:
The San Marcos creek is the main source for many small connecting streams such as: the [[Encinitas Creek]], [[Discovery Creek]], [[Copper Creek]], and the [[Leo Carillo Creek]].
Wildlife: The San Marcos creek is a prime habitat for many native and non-native species such as: [[Red-eared slider|Red-eared Slider Turtles]], [[Western pond turtle|Western pond turtles]], [[Pacific Tree Frog]], [[Western Toad|Western toad,]] [[Slender salamander|Slender Salamanders]], [[Channel catfish]], [[Wild boar]], [[Mule deer]], [[coyote]], [[gray fox]], [[mountain lion,]] [[Crayfish|crawfish]] and more.
<gallery> [[File:Lake San Marcos Dam Overflowing.jpg|thumb|Lake San Marcos Dam]]
</gallery>
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}

{{Infobox film | name = The Boondock Saints III | image = | alt = | caption = | native_name = <!-- {{Infobox name module|language|title}} or {{Infobox name module|title}} --> | director = [[Troy Duffy]] | writer = | screenplay = {{ubl|Troy Duffy|[[Sean Patrick Flanery]]}} | story = | based_on = <!-- {{Based on|title of the original work|creator of the original work|additional creator(s), if necessary}} --> | producer = {{Plainlist| * Shaun Redick * Yvette Yates Redick * [[Don Carmody]] * Troy Duffy }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Sean Patrick Flanery]] * [[Norman Reedus]] }} | narrator = | cinematography = | editing = | music = | studio = Impossible Dream Entertainment<!-- or: | production_companies = --> | distributor = <!-- or: | distributors = --> | released = <!-- {{Film date|df=yes/no|year|month|day|location|ref1=}} --> | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Boondock Saints III''''' is an upcoming [[vigilante film|vigilante]] [[action thriller|action-thriller film]] directed by [[Troy Duffy]] who wrote the script with [[Sean Patrick Flanery]]. The film will be the third in the series, serving as a [[sequel]] to the 2009 film ''[[The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day]]''. The film stars [[Sean Patrick Flanery]] and [[Norman Reedus]], who reprise their roles as the MacManus brothers.
== Cast == * [[Sean Patrick Flanery]] as Connor MacManus * [[Norman Reedus]] as Murphy MacManus
== Production == At the 2021 [[American Film Market]], progress on development of ''The Boondock Saints III'' was announced, bringing [[Troy Duffy]], [[Norman Reedus]], and [[Sean Patrick Flanery]] back together for the third film in the series. Duffy and Flannery co-wrote the script with with input from Reedus, and Duffy would direct as well. Filming is planned for May 2022.<ref name="AFM" />
== References == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="AFM">{{cite web |last1=Fleming |first1=Mike Jr |title=Norman Reedus, Sean Patrick Flanery & Director Troy Duffy Reunite For 'The Boondock Saints III' – AFM |url=https://deadline.com/2021/11/boondock-saints-3-norman-reedus-sean-patrick-flanery-troy-duffy-reunite-hot-afm-title-1234865849/ |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]] |date=November 1, 2021}}</ref> }}

[[File:Francisco_Jorquera,_Manifestación_xuízo_Prestige_(Headshot_retouched).jpg|thumb|upright]] '''Francisco Xesús Jorquera Caselas''' (born 31 August 1961) is a Spanish politician of the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]] (BNG). He was a [[Senate of Spain|Senator]] (2005–08) and a member of the [[Congress of Deputies]] (2008–2012), and led his party in the [[Parliament of Galicia]] from 2012 to 2016.
==Biography== Born in [[Ferrol, Galicia|Ferrol]], Jorquera graduated in Geography and History from the [[University of Santiago de Compostela]]. While there, he was the secretary general of the [[Galician Revolutionary Students]] (ERGA) and a member of the [[Galician National-Popular Assembly]] (ANPG), before partaking in the foundation of the [[Galician Nationalist Bloc]] (BNG) in 1982. He was a member of the party's national council in the early 1980s and again from 2001, joining its executive in 2003.<ref name=van>{{cite news |title=Francisco Jorquera: la esencia del BNG|trans-title=Francisco Jorquera: the essence of the BNG|url=https://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20121001/54352147794/francisco-jorquera-bng.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=[[La Vanguardia]] |date=1 October 2012 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
Jorquera was a member of the [[Senate of Spain]] from 2005 to 2008, being appointed by the [[Parliament of Galicia]] and the only BNG member in the upper house of the [[Cortes Generales]]. [[2008 Spanish general election|In 2008]], he was elected to the [[Congress of Deputies]] to represent [[A Coruña (Congress of Deputies constituency)|A Coruña]], and was re-elected [[2011 Spanish general election|in 2011]].<ref name=van/>
In January 2012, Jorquera was chosen as the BNG's lead candidate for the [[2012 Galician regional election]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Beramendi |first1=Mario |title=La UPG elige a Francisco Jorquera como candidato del BNG a la Xunta|trans-title=UPG chooses Francisco Jorquera as BNG candidate for the Xunta |url=https://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/galicia/2012/01/15/upg-elige-jorquera-candidato-bng-xunta/00031326648681676394660.htm |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=[[La Voz de Galicia]] |date=16 January 2012 |language=Spanish}}</ref> The results in October saw his party come fourth, falling by five seats to seven.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Salgado |first1=Daniel |title=El BNG califica de “muy malos” sus resultados y no culpa a nadie|trans-title=BNG describes its results as "very bad" and blames nobody|url=https://elpais.com/ccaa/2012/10/22/galicia/1350933789_985486.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=[[El País]] |date=23 October 2012 |language=Spanish}}</ref> In 2016, shortly before the [[2016 Galician regional election|next election]], he ceded his responsibilities to the next candidate, [[Ana Pontón]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Pontón reemplazará a Jorquera en las preguntas a Feijóo en el Parlamento|trans-title=Pontón will replace Jorquera in questioning Feijóo in Parliament|url=https://www.diariodepontevedra.es/articulo/galicia/ponton-reemplazara-jorquera-en-las-preguntas-feijoo-en-el-parlamento/20160516143750301107.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=Diario de Pontevedra |date=16 May 2016 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
Jorquera was chosen in June 2018 as the BNG's leader for the [[2019 Spanish local elections|2019 local election]] in [[A Coruña]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gutiérrez |first1=José Manuel |title=Jorquera será el candidato del BNG y apuesta por un "cambio real" para la ciudad|trans-title=Jorquera will be the BNG candidate and bets on a "real change" for the city|url=https://www.laopinioncoruna.es/coruna/2018/06/23/jorquera-sera-candidato-bng-apuesta-24032973.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=La Opinión A Coruña |date=23 June 2018 |language=Spanish}}</ref> His party rose from one councillor to two, and voted for [[Inés Rey]] of the [[Socialist Party of Galicia]] (PSdeG) to be mayor.<ref>{{cite news |title=Elecciones Municipales: El PSOE recupera la Alcaldía de A Coruña pero necesitará apoyos para gobernar |trans-title=Local Elections: PSOE recover the mayoralty of A Coruña bt will need support to govern|url=https://www.laopinioncoruna.es/elecciones/municipales/2019/05/26/elecciones-municipales-psoe-recupera-alcaldia-23773731.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=La Opinión A Coruña|date=26 May 2019 |language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Lombao |first1=David |title=La socialista Inés Rey es elegida primera alcaldesa democrática de A Coruña con una llamada al "entendimiento"|trans-title=Socialist Inés Rey is elected the first female democratic mayor of A Coruña with a call for "understanding"|url=https://www.eldiario.es/galicia/ines-rey-democratica-coruna-entendimiento_1_1500549.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=[[ElDiario.es]] |date=15 June 2019 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Jorquera, Francisco}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:People from Ferrol, Spain]] [[Category:University of Santiago de Compostela alumni]] [[Category:Galician Nationalist Bloc politicians]] [[Category:Members of the 9th Parliament of Galicia]] [[Category:Members of the 9th Congress of Deputies (Spain)]] [[Category:Members of the 10th Congress of Deputies (Spain)]] [[Category:Members of the 8th Senate of Spain]]

'''Anastasiia Mertsalova''' (born {{birth date|2001|07|3|df=yes}}) is an [[Azerbaijan|Azerbaijani]] [[volleyball]] player.
She competed at the [[2021 Women's European Volleyball Championship]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Teams {{!}} EuroVolley|url=https://eurovolley.cev.eu/en/women/teams/team/11830-azerbaijan|access-date=2021-11-01|website=eurovolley.cev.eu}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Women {{!}} CEV|url=https://www.cev.eu/national-team/european-league/european-golden-league/women/team/12108-azerbaijan/player/86999-mertsalova-anastasiia|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.cev.eu}}</ref>
She plays for Maccabi Hod Hasharon.

revision.text:
'''Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu (b. 1977)''' is an award winning [[Zimbabwe]]-born novelist and filmmaker.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Press|first=Author Catalyst|date=2021-01-13|title=Q&A with Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu|url=https://www.catalystpress.org/qa-with-siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=CatalystPress|language=en-US}}</ref> Though she was born and partly grew up in the city of [[Bulawayo]], Ndlovu has lived, studied and worked in various places including [[South Africa]], [[Sweden]] and the [[United States]].
== Background == A few months after she was born, Ndlovu's family moved to [[Sweden]] as political refugees, and this is where she spent the formative years of her life. The family then moved to the United States, and returned to [[Zimbabwe]] after 1980 when the country had attained its independence. She attended [[Girls' College|Girls College]] and thereafter went to the [[United States|US]] to pursue her university studies in [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]] ([[Emerson College]]); [[Athens, Ohio]] ([[Ohio University]]) and [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]], [[California]] ([[Stanford University]]).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu {{!}} Modern Thought & Literature|url=https://mtl.stanford.edu/people/siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu|access-date=2021-11-01|website=mtl.stanford.edu|language=en}}</ref> She spent 18 years in the [[United States|US]], before she decided to move back to [[Africa]] where she lived between [[South Africa]] and [[Zimbabwe]].
== Writing career == Ndlovu's fiction has been gaining so much critical acclaim since she entered the scene in 2018. Her debut book, ''The Theory of Flight'' (2018)<ref>{{Cite web|title=In Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu’s debut novel there is no distinction between the real and the magical, writes Kate Sidley|url=http://bookslive.co.za/blog/2018/10/16/in-siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu%e2%80%99s-debut-novel-there-is-no-distinction-between-the-real-and-the-magical-writes-kate-sidley/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Sunday Times Books LIVE @ Sunday Times Books LIVE|language=en}}</ref> was soon followed by ''The History of Man'' (2020). The two books have won praise, made it on shortlists, and earned their author places at prestigious fellowships around the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu in conversation with Drew Shaw in her hometown of Bulawayo, April 2021|url=https://www.centre-for-english-excellence.com/articles/siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu-in-conversation-with-drew-shaw-in-her-hometown-of-bulawayo-april-2021|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Centre for English Excellence - Bulawayo|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Debeernecessities|first=~|date=2021-02-02|title=AUTHOR SIPHIWE GLORIA NDLOVU IS A FORCE OF NATURE IN LITERARY WORLD|url=https://debeernecessities.com/2021/02/02/author-siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu-is-a-force-of-nature-in-literary-world/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=De Beer Necessities|language=en}}</ref> Besides creative writing, Ndlovu is a trained literary scholar.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-01-13|title=On Discovering Zimbabwean Literature as a Zimbabwean Writer|url=https://lithub.com/on-discovering-zimbabwean-literature-as-a-zimbabwean-writer/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Literary Hub|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=https://www.timeslive.co.za/authors/nalibali|title='Fiction can save us from ourselves' - Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/sunday-times/books/news/2020-11-23-fiction-can-save-us-from-ourselves-siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu/|access-date=2021-11-01|website=TimesLIVE|language=en-ZA}}</ref> She is also a filmmaker, her films have premiered at the Zanzibar International Film Festival among others.<ref>{{Citation|title=Tête-à-Tête with Siphiwe Ndlovu moderated by Marlene Schneider #ABF 2019|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dsoBOCzQoAM| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211101/dsoBOCzQoAM| url-status=live| archive-date=2021-11-01|language=en|access-date=2021-11-01}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Murmures {{!}} Africultures : Dhow Awards du Zanzibar International Film Festival|url=http://africultures.com/murmures/?no=871&utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=504|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Africultures|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
== Awards == Miles Morland Writing Scholarship (2018)<ref>{{Cite web|title=Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu - The Miles Morland Foundation|url=https://milesmorlandfoundation.com/siphiwe-gloria-ndlovu/|access-date=2021-11-01|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Publications == ''The Theory of Flight'' (Penguin Random House, 2018)<ref>{{Cite book|last=Ndlovu|first=Siphiwe Gloria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1_dmDwAAQBAJ&newbks=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=inauthor:%22Siphiwe+Gloria+Ndlovu%22&hl=en|title=The Theory of Flight|date=2018-08-01|publisher=Penguin Random House South Africa|isbn=978-1-4152-1011-6|language=en}}</ref>
''The History of Man'' (Penguin Random House, 2020)<ref>{{Cite book|last=Ndlovu|first=Siphiwe Gloria|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/The_History_of_Man.html?id=UH4pzgEACAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=The History of Man|date=2022-01-11|publisher=CATALYST Press|isbn=978-1-946395-56-6|language=en}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Uncategorized|date=November 2021}}

revision.text:
{{short description|American college football season}} {{Infobox college sports team season | year = 1999 | team = Northwestern Oklahoma State Rangers | sport = football | image = | image_size = | conference = Independent | record = 13–0 | head_coach = [[Tim Albin]] | hc_year = 3rd | captain = | stadium = | champion = NAIA national champion | bowl = [[NAIA Football National Championship|NAIA Championship Game]] | bowl_result = W 34-26 vs {{cfb link|year=1999|team=Georgetown Tigers|title=Georgetown (KY)}} }} {{1999 NAIA independents football records}} The '''1999 Northwestern Oklahoma State Rangers football team''' was an [[American football]] team that represented the [[Northwestern Oklahoma State University]] as an independent during the [[1999 NAIA football season]]. In their third season under head coach [[Tim Albin]], the Rangers compiled a perfect 13–0 record and was the NAIA national champion, defeating {{cfb link|year=1999|team=Georgetown Tigers|title=Georgetown (Kentucky)}}, 34-26, in the [[NAIA Football National Championship|NAIA Championship Game]].<ref>{{cite web|title=1999 National Championship Team|publisher=Northwestern Oklahoma State University|accessdate=November 1, 2021|url=https://riderangersride.com/honors/hall-of-fame/1999-national-championship-team/64}}</ref>
==Schedule== {{CFB schedule | attend = y | source = y
|September 24||{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Lambuth Eagles|title=Lambuth}}||Alva, OK|W 39-15||
|October 2||{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Fort Hays State Tigers|title=Fort Hays State}}|||W 35-7||
|November 13||{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Wayne State Wildcats|title=Wayne State (NE)}}|Ranger Field|Alva, OK|W 71-30|3,150|
|November 20||{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Southwestern Moundbuilders|title=Southwestern (KS)}}|| (NAIA championship series first round)|W 44-10||
|November 27||Lambuth|| (NAIA championship series quarterfinal)|W 56-13||
|December 4||{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Mary Marauders|title=Mary (ND)}}|| (NAIA championship series semifinal)|W 21-6||
|December 18|vs|{{cfb link|year=1999|team=Georgetown Tigers|title=Georgetown (KY)}}||[[Savannah, Tennessee|Savannah, TN]] ([[NAIA Football National Championship|NAIA Championship Game]])|W 34-26|6,500 (est)| }}
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Andrey Kulagin | native_name = Андрей Михайлович Кулагин | image = Andrey Mikhailovich Kulagin.jpg | birth_date = 4 September 1921 | birth_place = [[:ru:Старое Закружье|Staroe Zakruzhye]], [[Byelorussian SSR]]
(located within present-day [[Vietka District]], [[Gomel Oblast]] | death_date = 20 August 1980 (aged 58) | death_place = [[Minsk]], Byelorussian SSR, USSR | allegiance = {{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Soviet Union]] | branch = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Soviet Air Force.svg}} [[Soviet Air Forces|Soviet Air Force]] | rank = Colonel | serviceyears = 1940—1955 | unit = | commands = | battles = [[World War II]] | awards = [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] }} '''Andrey Mikhailovich Kulagin''' ({{lang-ru|Андрей Михайлович Кулагин}}; 4 September 1921 — 20 August 1980) was a Soviet fighter pilot who became a flying ace during [[World War II]]. Awarded the title [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] on 1 July 1944 for his initial victories, by the end of the war he totaled 30 solo and five shared shootdowns. After the end of the war he remained in the military, reaching the rank of colonel.{{Cite book|last=Bykov|first=Mikhail|title=Все асы Сталина. 1936–1953|publisher=Yauza|year=2014|isbn=978-5-9955-0712-3|location=Moscow|pages=646-647|trans-title=Aces of Stalin. 1936–1953|oclc=879321002}}{{Cite web|last=Ufarkin|first=Nikolai|title=Кулагин Андрей Михайлович|url=https://warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=9990|url-status=live|access-date=2021-11-01|website=warheroes.ru|language=ru}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kulagin, Andrey}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet World War II flying aces]] [[Category:Heroes of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Banner]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Alexander Nevsky]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Red Star]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox law firm | name = Cohen Milstein | logo = | image_size = | alt = | headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]] | num_offices = 6 | offices = | num_attorneys = 100 | num_employees = | practice_areas = | key_people = | revenue = | profit_per_equity_partner = | date_founded = | founder = | company_type = | dissolved = | website = {{URL|https://www.cohenmilstein.com}} }}
'''Cohen Milstein''' is an American plaintiffs' law firm that engages in large-scale class action litigation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Merken |first1=Sara |title=Cohen Milstein says cyber incident may have affected 'small subset' of firm's data |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/legal/cohen-milstein-says-cyber-incident-may-have-affected-small-subset-firms-data-2021-05-24/ |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=Reuters |date=24 May 2021 |language=en}}</ref> The firm filed a number of lawsuits against [[Donald Trump]] during and after his presidency. Cohen Milstein has been hired by various state attorneys general to assist in complex litigation, including by suing [[ExxonMobil]] over climate change. [[Anita Hill]] is of counsel at the firm.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thompson |first1=Krissah |title=For Anita Hill, the Clarence Thomas hearings haven’t really ended |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/for-anita-hill-the-clarence-thomas-hearings-havent-really-ended/2011/10/05/gIQAy2b5QL_story.html |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=Washington Post |date=6 October 2011}}</ref>
==Lawsuits against Donald Trump==
The firm assisted District of Columbia Attorney General [[Karl Racine]] and [[Attorney General of Maryland]] [[Brian Frosh]] in filing a lawsuit accusing President [[Donald Trump]] of using his hotel in Washington D.C. to unconstitutionally profit from his political office.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Woellert |first1=Lorraine |last2=Gerstein |first2=Josh |title=Judge green-lights subpoenas in Trump Hotel lawsuit |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/12/03/subpoenas-trump-hotel-emoluments-1041324 |work=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref> ''[[D.C. and Maryland v. Trump]]'' alleged that Trump had violated the [[Foreign Emoluments Clause]]. In January 2021, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] issued a summary disposition ordering the Fourth Circuit to dismiss the case as moot.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shah |first1=Maryam |title=DC AG Racine, AG Frosh on Conclusion of Emoluments Lawsuit |url=https://www.stl.news/dc-ag-racine-ag-frosh-on-conclusion-of-emoluments-lawsuit/433247/ |access-date=1 November 2021 |publisher=STL News |date=25 January 2021}}</ref>
In February 2021, on behalf of Democratic U.S. Representative [[Bennie Thompson]], Cohen Milstein and the [[NAACP]] filed a lawsuit against former President Trump and [[Rudy Giuliani]] over their role in the [[2021 United States Capitol attack]]. The lawsuit alleged that Trump and Giuliani had collaborated and conspired with the white supremacist groups [[Proud Boys]] and [[Oath Keepers]] to prevent the U.S. Congress from certifying the results of the 2020 presidential election.<ref>{{cite news |last1=King |first1=Maya |title=NAACP sues Trump and Giuliani after Jan. 6 riots |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/16/naacp-trump-giuliani-capitol-riots-469077 |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=POLITICO |date=February 16, 2016 |language=en}}</ref> A number of congressional Democrats signed onto the lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Swanson |first1=Ian |title=10 Democrats join NAACP lawsuit against Trump |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/546877-ten-democrats-join-naacp-lawsuit-against-trump |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=TheHill |date=7 April 2021 |language=en}}</ref>
==Lawsuits on behalf of state attorneys general==
Cohen Milstein has a practice area in which it helps state attorneys general with complex litigation.<ref name=hill>{{cite news |last1=Mali |first1=Meghashyam |title=Exxon allies cry foul over law firm in climate probe |url=https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/288924-exxon-allies-cry-foul-over-law-firm-in-climate-probe |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=TheHill |date=23 July 2016 |language=en}}</ref> In 2014, ''The New York Times'' wrote that Cohen Milstein was part of "a flourishing industry that pairs plaintiffs' lawyers with state attorneys general to sue companies, a collaboration that has set off a furious competition between trial lawyers and corporate lobbyists to influence these officials."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lipton |first1=Eric |title=Lawyers Create Big Paydays by Coaxing Attorneys General to Sue |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/us/politics/lawyers-create-big-paydays-by-coaxing-attorneys-general-to-sue-.html |access-date=26 October 2021 |work=The New York Times |date=19 December 2014}}</ref> The firm has been a major donor to state attorneys general associations, candidates, state party committees, and attorneys general running for governor.<ref>{{cite news |title=Political Gifts from Plaintiffs’ Lawyers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/12/19/us/politics/political-gifts-from-plaintiffs-lawyers.html |access-date=26 October 2021 |work=The New York Times |date=18 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2016, the Attorney General of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Claude Walker, authorized the firm to investigate whether [[ExxonMobil]] had committed fraud by denying climate change.<ref name=hill/> Cohen Milstein stood to earn as much as 27% percent of any monetary damages generated by the litigation, plus some costs. That arrangement was criticized by Exxon, who said it gave the law firm an inappropriate profit motive and that Walker had ceded too much authority to outside lawyers by authorizing them to act as prosecutors. Exxon sued Cohen Milstein, arguing the firm wasn't disinterested in the case because it stood to earn a contingency fee. Exxon's suit alleged constitutional violations regarding free speech, due process, and unreasonable searches and seizures.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cassens Weiss |first1=Debra |title=Exxon sues law firm that sought climate change documents |url=https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/exxon_sues_law_firm_seeking_climate_change_documents |access-date=1 November 2021 |work=ABA Journal |date=April 18, 2016 |language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Privately held companies of the United States]] [[Category:Law firms based in Washington, D.C.]]

{{Draft article}}{{Infobox person | name = Ashkan Khatibi | image = Ashkan Khatibi.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]]، [[Iran]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * [[Actor]] * [[Singer]] * [[Director]]}} | agent = | website = | spouse = [[Anahita Dargahi]] | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = solo_singer | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Pop]] * [[Rock]]}} | instrument = {{flatlist| * [[Guitar]] * [[Piano]] }}
| label = {{flatlist| Nedaye Chang}} | associated_acts = Traffic Band }} }}
Ashkan Khatibi (born October 10, 1979, in Shemiran, Tehran) is an Iranian actor, singer, presenter, and director. He continued his education until his bachelor's degree in theater from the Faculty of Art and Architecture of Azad University. In 1979, together with Babak Saeedi, they had a band called Apollo, which played Iranian rock but left the band. He plays the piano, guitar, and sometimes the mouth instrument.<ref>{{یادکرد خبر|عنوان=در مصاحبه اختصاصی با آفتاب مطرح شد؛ اشکان خطیبی: کلاه قرمزی بهترین کار سالهای اخیر بود! ماجراجو نیستم، دوست دارم تجربه کنم|بازیابی=۰۷ ژوئن ۲۰۱۲|پیوند=http://www.aftabnews.ir/vglg7n97.ak93qa1rrqp4a.v.html|ناشر=آفتاب|accessdate=۷ ژوئن ۲۰۱۲|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526002311/http://www.aftabnews.ir/vglg7n97.ak93qa1rrqp4a.v.html|archivedate=۲۶ مه ۲۰۱۲|dead-url=yes}}</ref> In addition to music and acting, he sometimes translates English plays into Persian and is also the director of the Traffic Music Band.<ref name="musicema.com">http://www.musicema.com/node/172092</ref>
== Activities ==
* Playing in the telefilm "Wage of Love" directed by "Mahmoud Maghami" * Playing in the telefilm "Spring Before and After" directed by "Shahid Ahmadlou" * Playing in the telefilm "Ekbatan" directed by "Saeed Asadi" * Playing in the telefilm "End of the Highway" directed by "Farzad Mothman"; 2012
=== Translation === Wild Love and the Curse of the Famine by Sam Shepard entitled Love and the Curse
=== TV Presenter ===
* New Design House (2007-2008) * Baharestan (Special Nowruz-2014) * Five Stars (2017-2017)
== Music == Ashkan Khatibi is also the singer of the Traffic Band.<ref>http://www.asriran.com/fa/news/269136/وقتی-اشکان-خطیبی-خواننده-می‌شود</ref>
* Traffic Album, Traffic Group (2012) * Hard days of titration of Sin program like serial * The Relatively Bad Kids song (Nightmare) for the title track of the Relatively Bad Kids series, which for some reason was replaced by another title track. * A simple death * My life (speech) * The last curtain of * This year is our year 2016 * Cry girl September 26, 2016 * Silver curtain * Give me your hand 1398 (single song)
== References == <references group=""></references>
== External Links ==
* {{IMDb name|4346542}} * {{Instagram|ashkan}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Khatibi, Ashkan}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Mark Boitano | state_senate = New Mexico | district = 18th | term_start = January 1997 | term_end = January 2013 | successor = [[Lisa Torraco‎]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|July 19, 1953}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], U.S. | education = [[Excelsior College|Regents College]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]]) | relations = [[Brian Boitano]] (brother) }}
'''Mark L. Boitano''' (born July 19, 1953) is an American politician and real estate agent who served as a member of the [[New Mexico Senate]] for the 18th district from 1997 to 2015.
== Early life and education == Boitano was born in [[San Francisco]] and graduated from [[Bellarmine College Preparatory]] in [[San Jose, California]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Boitano Team {{!}} Albuquerque Homes for Sale, Property Search in Albuquerque|url=https://www.markboitano.com/about-the-boitano-team|access-date=2021-11-01|website=markboitano.com|language=en}}</ref> He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in political science from [[Excelsior College|Regents College]] in 1989.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark Boitano's Biography|url=https://justfacts.votesmart.org/candidate/biography/10319/mark-boitano|url-status=live|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Vote Smart}}</ref>
== Career == Boitano was elected to the [[New Mexico Senate]] in 1996 and assumed office in 1997. Boitano did not seek re-election in 2012 and left office in January 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Updated: ABQ Sen. Mark Boitano Not Seeking Re-Election - Albuquerque Journal|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/90543/abq-sen-mark-boitano-not-seeking-re-election.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.abqjournal.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=New Mexico Senator Won't Seek Re-Election After 4 Terms|url=https://www.krwg.org/post/new-mexico-senator-wont-seek-re-election-after-4-terms|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.krwg.org|language=en}}</ref> During his tenure, Boitano also served as ranking member of the Senate Corporations and Transportation. Since 1992, Boitano has worked as a real estate broker.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark Boitano|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Mark_Boitano|access-date=2021-11-01|website=Ballotpedia|language=en}}</ref>
== Personal life == Boitano's brother, [[Brian Boitano]], is a retired Olympic figure skater.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mark Boitano says his brother's legacy is more than his sexuality - Albuquerque Journal|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/350280/boitano-says-brothers-legacy-is-more-than-his-sexuality.html|access-date=2021-11-01|website=www.abqjournal.com}}</ref>
== References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Boitano, Mark}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from San Francisco]] [[Category:People from Albuquerque, New Mexico]] [[Category:Politicians from Albuquerque, New Mexico]] [[Category:New Mexico Republicans]] [[Category:New Mexico state senators]] [[Category:Excelsior College alumni]]

|date=November 2021}}
'''Alisovo-Pokrovskoye''' ({{lang-ru|links=no|Алисово-Покровское}}) is a [[types of inhabited localities in Russia|rural locality]] ({{Lang-ru|село|lit=village}}) in Soldatsky Selsoviet Rural Settlement, [[Fatezhsky District]], [[Kursk Oblast]], [[Russia]]. Population: {{ru-census|p2010=83|p2002=89|p1989=77}}
== Geography == The village is located on the Nikovets River (a right tributary of the Ruda in the basin of the Svapa), 94 km from the [[Russia–Ukraine border]], 40 km north-west of [[Kursk]], 11 km south-west of the district center – the town [[Fatezh]], 13 km from the selsoviet center – [[Soldatskoye, Fatezhsky District, Kursk Oblast|Soldatskoye]].<ref name="geo">{{cite web|url=https://publichnaya-kadastrovaya-karta.com/kurskaya/fatezhskij_alisovo-pokrovskoe?obj=87304|title=Real estate report: Alisovo-Pokrovskoye|publisher=publichnaya-kadastrovaya-karta.com|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}}</ref>
; Climate Alisovo-Pokrovskoye has a warm-summer [[humid continental climate]] (''Dfb'' in the [[Köppen climate classification]]).
== Transport == Alisovo-Pokrovskoye is located 11 km from the federal route {{Road marker simple|-|M-2|#0090ff|white|-}} [[M2 highway (Russia)|Crimea Highway]] as part of the European route [[European route E105|E105]], 13.5 km from the road of regional importance {{Road marker simple|-|38K-038|#0090ff|white|-}} (Fatezh – [[Dmitriyev (town)|Dmitriyev]]), on the road of intermunicipal significance {{Road marker simple|-|38Н-826|#0090ff|white|-}} (Alisovo-Pokrovskoye – [[Kofanovka, Fatezhsky District, Kursk Oblast|Kofanovka]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/w/images/a/ac/38._Перечень_автодорог.pdf|title=Постановление Администрации Курской области от 28.07.2006 N 76 (ред. от 16.09.2020) "Об утверждении Перечня автомобильных дорог общего пользования регионального и межмуниципального значения Курской области" (дата сохранения: 23.01.2021) / Resolution of the Administration of the Kursk Oblast of July 28, 2006 Nr 76 (as amended on September 16, 2020) "On approval of the List of public roads of regional and intermunicipal significance of the Kursk Oblast" (save date: 01/23/2021)|publisher=openstreetmap.org|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}}</ref> 32 km from the nearest railway halt ''552 km''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://railwayz.info/photolines/station/7014|title=о.п. 552 км|publisher=railwayz.info|lang=ru|accessdate=2021-11-01}}</ref> (railway line Navlya – Lgov-Kiyevsky).
The rural locality is situated 44 km from [[Kursk Vostochny Airport]], 158 km from [[Belgorod International Airport]] and 239 km from [[Voronezh International Airport|Voronezh Peter the Great Airport]].
